 23. October 27 23.1. Countable Sets Recall that a countably infinite set is a set S that has the same cardinality as N. This represents the smallest size of an infinite set, making it a natural starting point for exploring results about the sizes of infinite sets, which often defy intuition. For instance, we have already shown that there exists a bijection f : N →2N. This implies that |2N|= |N|, even though 2N ⊊N. In other words, there are just as many natural numbers as there are even natural numbers. We have also previously encountered bijections g : N →Z and h : N →N2. Thus, we can conclude that |2N|= |N|= |Z|= |N2|. Next, we will prove some important results about countable sets, beginning with a classic example. We will present two different proofs of this result: the traditional “snaking proof” and an alternative argument using the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder (CBS) Theorem. 23.1.1. Countability of the Rationals Theorem 23.1.1. The set of rational numbers Q is countably infinite. Proof. We aim to demonstrate the existence of a bijection f : N →Q. In other words, we seek an explicit way to enumerate all rational numbers so that every rational number appears at a finite position in the list. To do so, we arrange all rational numbers of the form a b in a two-dimensional array, where a ∈Z and b ∈Z+. Each entry of this array represents one rational number. We then traverse this array diagonally to ensure that every rational number is encountered within a finite number of steps. Since each diagonal contains only finitely many entries, this process covers the entire array. Beginning at 0, we “snake” our way through the diagonals, skipping any fractions that are not in lowest terms, as illustrated below. 146

 This traversal defines a function f : N →Q recursively, assigning to each natural number the corresponding rational number in the sequence. The beginning of this enumeration may be represented as follows: x 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 · · · f(x) 0 1 1 2 −1 2 −1 2 1 3 1 4 −1 3 · · · Every rational number appears exactly once in this list, and each appears at a finite index, establishing a bijection f : N →Q. Hence, Q is countably infinite. We now present an alternative proof that Q is countably infinite, this time using the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder (CBS) Theorem. For this proof, we assume the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, which we have partially established. Theorem 23.1.2 (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic (FTOA)). Every integer greater than 1 can be written uniquely as a product of prime numbers. We have already shown that every integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes. In a later section on number theory, we will prove the uniqueness of this factorization. For the purposes of this proof, we assume the full validity of the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic. Theorem 23.1.3. The set Q is countably infinite. Proof. We will construct injections f : N →Q and g : Q →N. By the CBS Theorem, this will imply |N|= |Q|. 147

 • Define f : N →Q by f(n) = n 1 . If f(m) = f(n) for m, n ∈N, then m = n, so f is injective. Hence |N|≤|Q|. • To construct an injection g : Q →N, note that every rational number can be written uniquely in reduced form as a b, where a ∈Z, b ∈Z+, and gcd(a, b) = 1. Define g : Q →N by g a b  = ( 2a · 5b if a ≥0, 3−a · 5b if a < 0 where a b ∈Q is in reduced form. We now verify that g is injective. Suppose g(x) = g(y), where x = a1 b1 and y = a2 b2 , with ai ∈Z, bi ∈Z+, and gcd(ai, bi) = 1 for i = 1, 2. We consider three cases: ▶Case 1: a1, a2 ≥0. Then g(x) = g(y) implies 2a15b1 = 2a25b2. By the FTOA, we have a1 = a2 and b1 = b2. ▶Case 2: a1, a2 < 0. Then g(x) = g(y) implies 3−a15b1 = 3−a25b2, and again the FTOA gives a1 = a2 and b1 = b2. ▶Case 3: Without loss of generality, suppose a1 ≥0 and a2 < 0. Then 2a15b1 = 3−a25b2. By the FTOA, this forces a1 = a2 = 0, contradicting a2 < 0. Therefore, g is injective, and |Q|≤|N|. By the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder Theorem, we conclude that |N|= |Q|, so Q is countably infinite. We have already seen that several familiar sets are countable. We now establish some general results that allow us to construct new countable sets from previously known ones. 23.1.2. Properties of Countable Sets Recall that |N2|= |N|. Using this fact, together with induction, we can prove the following result. Theorem 23.1.4. For any n ∈Z+, |Nn|= ℵ0. Proof. Recall that |N2|= |N|, and let f : N2 →N be a bijection. We proceed by induction on n ∈Z+. • Base Case: For n = 1, we have |N1|= |N|= ℵ0, which holds by definition. 148

 • Inductive Step: Suppose that for some n ∈Z+, we have |Nn|= ℵ0. Then there exists a bijection g : Nn →N. Define a function h : Nn+1 →N2 by h((a1, a2, . . . , an), an+1) = (g(a1, a2, . . . , an), an+1). We show that h is a bijection. ▶Injectivity: Suppose h((a1, . . . , an), an+1) = h((b1, . . . , bn), bn+1). Then, by definition of h, (g(a1, . . . , an), an+1) = (g(b1, . . . , bn), bn+1), which implies that g(a1, . . . , an) = g(b1, . . . , bn) and an+1 = bn+1. Since g is injective, it follows that (a1, . . . , an) = (b1, . . . , bn), and hence ai = bi for all i ∈[n + 1]. Thus, h is injective. ▶Surjectivity: Let (x, y) ∈N2 be arbitrary. Since g is surjective, there exists (a1, . . . , an) ∈Nn such that g(a1, . . . , an) = x. Then for ((a1, . . . , an), y) ∈ Nn+1, h((a1, . . . , an), y) = (g(a1, . . . , an), y) = (x, y). Hence h is surjective. Since h is both injective and surjective, it is a bijection. Finally, the composition f ◦h : Nn+1 →N is a bijection, since it is the composition of two bijections. Therefore, |Nn+1|= |N|= ℵ0. By the principle of mathematical induction, we conclude that |Nn|= ℵ0 for all n ∈ Z+. Combining this result with the properties of finite Cartesian products, we obtain the following theorem. Theorem 23.1.5 (Finite Product of Countable Sets is Countable). If n ∈Z+ and X1, . . . , Xn are nonempty countable sets, then n Y i=1 Xi = X1 × X2 × · · · × Xn is countable. Moreover, if at least one Xi is infinite, then Qn i=1 Xi is countably infinite. 149

 We’ve seen that we can take finite Cartesian products of countable sets and remain countable. For unions of sets, we can do even better. The following result shows that a countably infinite union of countably infinite sets is still countably infinite. Theorem 23.1.6. Suppose {An}n∈N is a family of countably infinite sets. Then [ n∈N An is countably infinite. Proof. Let A = S n∈N An. We will show that ℵ0 ≤|A| and ℵ0 ≥|A|. • Since A0 is countably infinite, there exists a bijection f0 : N →A0. Define g : N → A by g(n) = f0(n). Because f0 is injective, g is also injective. Hence ℵ0 = |N|≤|A|. • For each n ∈N, let fn : N →An be a bijection (which exists because |An|= ℵ0 by assumption). Define h : N2 →A by h(n, m) = fn(m). We will show that h is surjective. Let a ∈A be arbitrary. Then a ∈An for some n ∈N. Fix such an n. Since fn is surjective, there exists m ∈N such that fn(m) = a. Thus h(n, m) = fn(m) = a. Because a ∈A was arbitrary, h is surjective. Therefore ℵ0 = |N2|≥|A|. By the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder Theorem and the partition principle, it follows that |A|= ℵ0, as desired. Since a countably infinite union of countably infinite sets is countably infinite, it follows that when we take either fewer unions or smaller sets, the union remains countable. Corollaries 23.1.7 (A Countable Union of Countable Sets is Countable). 1. If |A|= ℵ0 and |B|≤ℵ0, then |A ∪B|= ℵ0. 2. If {Ai}i∈N is a family of countable sets, then A = S i∈N Ai is countable. 3. If {Ai}i∈[n] (for some n ∈Z+) is a finite family of countable sets, then A = S i∈[n] Ai is countable. Moreover: a) If |Ai|= ℵ0 for at least one i ∈[n], then |A|= ℵ0. b) If each Ai is finite, then A is finite with |A|≥max{|Ai|}i∈[n]. Note. Regarding part (3b) in the previous corollary, we will discuss a formula for determining |A| in the combinatorics section later in the semester. 150

 Exercise 23.1.8. Show that the following sets are countably infinite. (a) A = {f : {0, 1} →N | f is a function} (b) B = the set of circles in R2 whose centers have integer coordinates and whose radii have rational lengths. (c) C = {f : N →N | ∀x ∈N, f(x + 1) = f(x) + 1} (d) D = the set of all “words”, where a “word” is a finite string of letters from the English alphabet. 23.2. Uncountable Sets So far, we have shown that many different infinite sets share the same size as N. This might naturally lead to the question: do uncountably infinite sets even exist? In this section, we will not only demonstrate that uncountably infinite sets do exist, but also establish that there are multiple distinct sizes (cardinalities) among uncountably infinite sets. Our main proof technique will be a powerful method known as diagonalization. 23.2.1. Uncountability of the Real Numbers To show that the real numbers are uncountable, we need to establish that there is no possible way to enumerate them. How can we prove that such an enumeration cannot exist? As is often done in mathematics, we will proceed by contradiction. To make this argument concrete, we will describe real numbers using their decimal expansions and apply a diagonalization argument. A real number x ∈R can be represented in its decimal form as x = x0.x1x2x3 · · · , where x0 ∈Z is the integer part, and xi ∈N with 0 ≤xi ≤9 for i ∈Z+ represent the decimal digits. For example, 5 6 = 0.83333 · · · = 0.83. Technical Note: Decimal representations are not always unique. In particular, a decimal that ends with an infinite sequence of 9’s is equal to the corresponding decimal that ends with an infinite sequence of 0’s. (This is usually proved in Calculus 2 using geometric series.) For example, 0.499999 · · · = 0.50000 · · · . To avoid this ambiguity, we adopt the following convention: a decimal representation of x ∈R is said to be in normalized form if it does not end with an infinite string of 9’s. 151

 Exercise 23.2.1. (For those who have taken Calculus 2) Suppose that x ∈[0, 1) has two distinct decimal expansions: x = 0.a1a2a3 · · · , x = 0.b1b2b3 · · · , where ai, bi ∈{0, 1, . . . , 9} for all i. Let M be the smallest positive integer such that aM ̸= bM and assume that aM > bM. Prove that: • ai = bi for all 1 ≤i < M, • aM = bM + 1, • ai = 0 and bi = 9 for all i > M. With this convention in place, we can now use diagonalization to prove that there are uncountably many real numbers in the interval (0, 1). 152

 24. October 29 24.1. Uncountable Sets 24.1.1. Uncountability of the Real Numbers Theorem 24.1.1. The open interval (0, 1) is uncountable. Proof. Let f : Z+ →(0, 1) be an arbitrary function. We aim to show that f is not surjective. For each n ∈Z+, write f(n) in normalized decimal form as f(1) = 0.c1,1c1,2c1,3 · · · f(2) = 0.c2,1c2,2c2,3 · · · f(3) = 0.c3,1c3,2c3,3 · · · f(4) = 0.c4,1c4,2c4,3 · · · ... ... We will construct a number x ∈(0, 1) such that x /∈Im(f). Define x by specifying its nth digit xn as xn = ( 1, if cn,n ̸= 1, 2, if cn,n = 1. By construction, xn ̸= cn,n for all n ∈Z+. Thus x differs from f(n) in the nth decimal place for every n, meaning x ̸= f(n) for all n ∈Z+. Since x ∈(0, 1) and x /∈Im(f), it follows that f is not surjective. Because f : Z+ →(0, 1) was chosen arbitrarily, this shows that ℵ0 = |Z+|< |(0, 1)|. Therefore, the interval (0, 1) is uncountable. Note. The proof above illustrates the general idea behind diagonalization: given any attempt to list all elements of a certain set (for example, f(1), f(2), f(3), . . . ), we construct a new element that systematically differs from each listed one in at least one place. More precisely, the diagonalization strategy involves the following pattern: 1. Assume, for contradiction, that an enumeration of the set exists. 153

 2. Represent each element in a way that exposes infinitely many “coordinates” or distinguishable components (for example, digits of a real number, or values of a sequence). 3. Construct a new element by changing the nth coordinate (or component) of the nth listed element in a deliberate way. 4. Conclude that this new element differs from every element in the list, contradicting the assumption of a complete enumeration. The key feature of diagonalization is that the new element disagrees with the nth listed element in the nth component, ensuring that it is distinct from every item in the list. This strategy generalizes beyond decimal expansions. In each case, the heart of the argument is the same: no enumeration can capture every possible object once we can systematically construct one that escapes the list. Corollary 24.1.2. R is uncountable, and |R|= |(0, 1)|. Proof. Define f : (0, 1) →R by f(x) = ln 1 −x x  . Proving that f is a bijection was left as an exercise earlier. Since (0, 1) is uncountable and f is a bijection, it follows that R is also uncountable. Corollary 24.1.3. For any a, b ∈R with a < b, each of the following sets is uncountable: • (a, b) • (a, b] • [a, b) • [a, b] • (−∞, b) • (−∞, b] • (a, ∞) • [a, ∞) 24.1.2. Cantor’s Theorem Our diagonalization argument for the real numbers revealed that (0, 1) cannot be enumerated by the natural numbers. Cantor’s Theorem extends this idea even further: for any set S, the collection of all its subsets—its power set—is strictly larger than S itself. Theorem 24.1.4 (Cantor’s Theorem). For any set S, we have |S|< |P(S)|. 154

 Notes. • If S is finite, Cantor’s Theorem can be verified directly. In Homework 7, we proved that |P([n])|= 2n for all n ∈N, and it can be proven by induction that n < 2n for all n ∈N. • For infinite sets S, the theorem implies an infinite hierarchy of distinct infinite cardinalities, obtained by repeatedly taking power sets. For example: |N|< |P(N)|< |P(P(N))|< |P(P(P(N)))|< · · · Proof. Let S be an arbitrary set, and suppose g : S →P(S) is any function. Define a set T ∈P(S) by T = {x ∈S | x /∈g(x)}. We will show that T ̸= g(x) for any x ∈S. Let x ∈S be arbitrary. ▶Case 1: Suppose x ∈T. Then, by definition of T, we have x /∈g(x). Hence x ∈T but x /∈g(x), so T ̸= g(x). ▶Case 2: Suppose x /∈T. Then, by definition of T, we have x ∈g(x). Hence x /∈T but x ∈g(x), so again T ̸= g(x). Thus T ̸= g(x) for every x ∈S, meaning T is not in the image of g. Therefore g is not surjective. Since g : S →P(S) was arbitrary, no surjection from S onto P(S) exists, and hence |S|< |P(S)|. The construction in the proof is another example of diagonalization, where we created a new set T that disagrees with each g(x) regarding the membership of x. Example 24.1.5. To illustrate Cantor’s Theorem for the case S = N, we will show that no surjection f : N →P(N) can exist. Let f : N →P(N) be an arbitrary function, and define T = {n ∈N | n /∈f(n)}. We claim that T is not equal to f(n) for any n ∈N. To get some intuition, let us look at a few examples. • Suppose f(0) = {0, 3}. Then 0 /∈T because 0 ∈f(0), so T ̸= f(0). • Suppose f(1) = {5}. Then 1 ∈T because 1 /∈f(1), so T ̸= f(1). • Suppose f(2) = N. Then 2 /∈T because 2 ∈f(2), so T ̸= f(2). • Suppose f(3) = {1, 2, 4}. Then 3 ∈T because 3 /∈f(3), so T ̸= f(3). In each case, T differs from f(n) at the element n itself. More generally, for any n ∈N, we have two cases: 155

 ▶Case 1: If n ∈f(n), then n /∈T, so T ̸= f(n). ▶Case 2: If n /∈f(n), then n ∈T, so T ̸= f(n). Thus, for every n ∈N, the set T differs from f(n) in at least one element—specifically, at the “diagonal position” n. This pattern of constructing a new object that disagrees with the n-th object at the n-th coordinate is the essence of the diagonalization method. Since T ∈P(N) and T ̸= f(n) for all n ∈N, we conclude that f is not a surjection. Therefore, |N|< |P(N)|. Diagonalization thus provides a systematic way to construct an element not listed in any proposed enumeration. 24.1.3. Infinite Binary Sequences The technique used in Cantor’s Theorem also applies to other sets with infinite structure. One important example is the set of all infinite binary sequences. Although this result was proven in recitation, we restate it here to highlight its connection with Cantor’s argument. Theorem 24.1.6. Define {0, 1}N as the set of all infinite sequences consisting of 0s and 1s. That is, {0, 1}N = {⟨ai⟩i∈N | ∀i ∈N, ai ∈{0, 1}} . Then {0, 1}N is uncountably infinite. Cantor’s diagonal argument can be adapted to this setting by assuming we have an enumeration of all infinite binary sequences and then constructing a new sequence that differs from the n-th sequence at its n-th position. The resulting sequence cannot appear in the list, proving that no enumeration can include every element of {0, 1}N. Conceptually, this result is equivalent to Cantor’s Theorem for P(N): each infinite binary sequence can be viewed as the characteristic function of a subset of N. Thus, {0, 1}N and P(N) have the same cardinality, providing another example of how diagonalization exposes uncountable structures. Exercise 24.1.7. Show that the following sets are uncountable. (a) A = {f : N →{0, 1} | f is a function} (b) B = {f : N →N | f is a function} (c) C = {f : N →N | f is a bijection} 156

 (d) D = the set of infinite sequences of integers. (e) E = R ∖Q[ √ 2] where Q[ √ 2] = {x ∈R | ∃a, b ∈Q, x = a + b √ 2} 157

 Part V. Number Theory 158

 25. October 29 25.1. Introduction Number theory is possibly the oldest field of mathematics, and much of modern mathematics has its roots in it. The simplest description of number theory is the study of arithmetic. Number theorists investigate the fundamental properties of the integers, exploring their structure and relationships. At the heart of this field lies the study of prime numbers, which play a central role. Many of the most famous unsolved problems in mathematics are found in number theory, often characterized by their simplicity to state but difficulty to solve. Examples of Number Theoretic Results and Conjectures 1. There are infinitely many ordered triples of positive integers (x, y, z) such that x2 + y2 = z2. 2. Fermat’s Last Theorem: There are no ordered triples of positive integers (x, y, z) such that xn + yn = zn for any n ≥3. 3. Lagrange’s Four-Square Theorem: Every nonnegative integer can be expressed as the sum of four perfect squares. For example, 35 = 52 + 32 + 12 + 02. 4. Goldbach’s Conjecture: Every even integer greater than 2 can be written as the sum of two prime numbers. For example, 14 = 3 + 11 (or 14 = 7 + 7). 5. Twin Prime Conjecture: There are infinitely many pairs of prime numbers of the form (p, p + 2). To begin our study of number theory, we will first review some relevant definitions and results from earlier sections. • A natural number n > 1 is called prime if its only divisors are 1 and itself. In other words, if n is prime and n = ab for a, b ∈N, then either a = 1 or b = 1 (Lecture 11). • A natural number n > 1 is called composite if there exist a, b ∈N such that 1 < a ≤b < n and n = ab. In other words, n > 1 and is not prime. • The natural number n = 1 is called a unit. 159

 • Every natural number n > 1 is either prime or can be expressed as a product of prime numbers (Theorem 11.1.7). We now state a useful result that was proved in class on September 8, and repeat the proof here for reference: Theorem 25.1.1. Let m, n ∈Z be nonzero integers. If m | n, then |m|≤|n|. Proof. Let m, n ∈Z ∖{0} such that m | n. Then there exists an integer a ∈Z such that n = ma. Since the absolute value function is multiplicative, we have |n|= |m|·|a|. Because m and n are nonzero, a ̸= 0, which implies |a|≥1. Therefore, |n|= |m|·|a|≥ |m|·1 = |m|. The following corollary is an immediate consequence of the theorem. Corollary 25.1.2. Let m, n ∈Z. If m | n and n | m, then m = ±n. From the definitions and results above, we know that every composite integer n has a prime factor p < n. In fact, we can say more: every composite integer n has a prime factor p ≤√n. This observation provides a straightforward (though inefficient) method for checking whether a natural number n is prime. Theorem 25.1.3. If n ∈N is composite, then n has a prime factor p such that p ≤√n. Proof. Let n ∈N be composite, and express n as n = ab for some a, b ∈N with 1 < a ≤b < n. We first show that a ≤√n. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that a > √n. Then n = (√n)2 < a2 ≤ab = n, which yields the contradiction n < n. Therefore, a ≤√n. Let p be any prime divisor of a (possibly a itself, if a is prime). Then p ≤a ≤√n and, since p | a and a | n, it follows by transitivity that p | n. Example 25.1.4. Use the previous theorem to determine whether 91 or 97 is prime. Observe that √ 91 < √ 97 < 10, and the only prime numbers less than 10 are 2, 3, 5, and 7. To determine whether 91 or 97 is prime, we need to check if they are divisible by 2, 3, 5, or 7. 160

 • It is clear that 2 ∤91 (since 91 is odd) and 5 ∤91 (since 91 does not end in 0 or 5). We also find that 3 ∤91, but we notice that 7 | 91 and 91 = 7 · 13. Thus, 91 is composite . • Similarly, 2 ∤97 and 5 ∤97. Checking for divisibility by 3 and 7, we find that 3 ∤97 and 7 ∤97. Therefore, 97 is prime . Exercise 25.1.5. Determine which of the following integers are primes. (a) 201 (b) 203 (c) 207 (d) 211 (e) 213 (f) 221 161

 26. October 31 26.1. GCDs, LCMs, and Linear Combinations By Theorem 25.1.1, if n is a nonzero integer, then n can have only finitely many divisors, since m | n implies |m|≤|n|. Because any two nonzero integers each have finitely many divisors, it is natural to define the greatest divisor common to both. In fact, we can relax this requirement so that only one of the integers must be nonzero. Definition. For a, b ∈Z, not both zero, an integer d is called a common divisor of a and b if d | a and d | b. Furthermore, d is called the greatest common divisor of a and b, denoted gcd(a, b), if d is the largest of their common divisors. Examples 26.1.1. 1. Consider m = 54 and n = 42. Set of divisors of 54 = {±1, ±2, ±3, ±6, ±9, ±18, ±27, ±54}, Set of divisors of 42 = {±1, ±2, ±3, ±6, ±7, ±14, ±21, ±42}, Set of common divisors = {±1, ±2, ±3, ±6}. Therefore, gcd(54, 42) = 6, the largest element from the set of common divisors. 2. gcd(−6, −15) = 3. Even though both integers are negative, the greatest common divisor is always taken to be positive. 3. gcd(0, 44) = 44. Since every integer divides 0, we have gcd(0, n) = |n| for any integer n ̸= 0. (The value gcd(0, 0) is undefined.) Since the divisors of −m are the same as those of m, it follows that gcd(m, n) = gcd(|m|, |n|). Therefore, we often restrict our attention to pairs of nonnegative integers. Definition. Let a, b ∈Z, not both zero. Then a and b are called relatively prime (or coprime) if gcd(a, b) = 1. The following theorem states that if we divide a and b by their greatest common divisor, then the resulting integers have no common divisors other than ±1. This simple but powerful result is foundational in the study of arithmetic. 162

(a) 5,15 (b) 0, 111 (c) −27, −45 (d) −90, 100 (e) 100, 121 (f) 1001, 289 26.1.1. The Euclidean Algorithm The Euclidean Algorithm is a well-known and efficient method for computing the greatest common divisor (GCD) of two integers. Its foundation rests on the following lemma. Theorem 26.1.4 (EA Theorem). Let a, b ∈Z with b ̸= 0. For any k ∈Z, gcd(a, b) = gcd(b, a −bk). Proof. We will show that a and b have the same set of common divisors as b and a −bk, using a double-containment argument. • Suppose c ∈Z is a common divisor of a and b, i.e., c | a and c | b. Then there exist x, y ∈Z such that a = cx and b = cy. It follows that a −bk = c(x −yk), so c | (a −bk). Thus, c is a common divisor of b and a −bk. 163

 • Conversely, suppose c ∈Z is a common divisor of b and a −bk, i.e., c | b and c | (a −bk). Then there exist x, y ∈Z such that b = cx and a −bk = cy. Hence, a = (a −bk) + bk = cy + cxk = c(y + xk), and therefore c | a. Thus, c is a common divisor of a and b. Since the two pairs share the same common divisors, it follows that gcd(a, b) = gcd(b, a− bk). Given that gcd(a, b) = gcd(|a|, |b|) and gcd(a, 0) = |a| (for a ̸= 0), the Euclidean Algorithm is used to find the GCD of two positive integers. Strategy: The Euclidean Algorithm Let a, b ∈Z with a > b > 0. • Set r0 = a and r1 = b. • For j ≥2, apply the Division Algorithm to divide rj−2 by rj−1, yielding rj−2 = qj−1rj−1 + rj, where 0 ≤rj < rj−1. • Terminate the process when rn = 0. • The last nonzero remainder, rn−1, is equal to gcd(a, b). The Idea. The algorithm produces a strictly decreasing sequence of nonnegative remainders: r0 > r1 > r2 > · · · > rn−1 > rn = 0. By the well-ordering property of the natural numbers, this sequence must eventually terminate with a remainder of 0. Applying Theorem 26.1.4 repeatedly gives gcd(a, b) = gcd(r0, r1) = gcd(r1, r2) = gcd(r2, r3) ... = gcd(rn−1, 0) = rn−1. This procedure will be clarified through a concrete example. 164

**Corollary:** Let A and B be subsets of a universal set U. Then 1. A ∩B = A ∪B 2. A ∪B = A ∩B 9.1.2. Cartesian Products In set theory, the Cartesian product of two sets provides a way to pair each element of one set with each element of another set. This operation is fundamental in many areas of mathematics, allowing us to construct ordered pairs and define relations and functions. The Cartesian product helps us explore the relationships between different sets in a structured manner.

**Proof:** We will prove both statements simultaneously. Define the set S ⊆Z+ by S = {c ∈Z+ | ∃x, y ∈Z, (ax + by = c)}. Since |a|+|b|∈S, the set S is non-empty. By the Well-Ordering Property, S has a least element. Let d = ma + nb, where m, n ∈Z, be the smallest element of S. To establish both conditions, we need to show that d = gcd(a, b). To show that d | a, let q, r ∈Z be such that 0 ≤r < d and a = dq + r, as guaranteed by the Division Algorithm. Solving for r and substituting d = ma + nb, we get: r = a −dq = a −(ma + nb)q = (1 −qm)a + (−qn)b. Thus, r can be written in the form ax + by, but since r < d, it must be that r /∈S, implying r = 0. Hence, d | a. An identical argument shows that d | b, making d a common divisor of a and b. To show that d is the greatest common divisor, let t ∈Z+ be a common divisor of a and b. Then there exist k, ℓ∈Z such that a = tk and b = tℓ. Substituting these into d = ma + nb, we obtain: d = mtk + ntℓ= t(mk + nℓ). Thus, t | d. Since both t and d are positive, we conclude t ≤d, establishing that d = gcd(a, b). Several useful consequences follow immediately from B´ezout’s Lemma. We will discuss many of these in recitation, but you are encouraged to try proving them on your own. One is left as an exercise below. 166

 Corollaries 26.1.10. Let a, b ∈Z, not both zero, and let d = gcd(a, b). 1. If t | a and t | b, then t | d. (Every common divisor divides the greatest common divisor.) 2. For all c ∈Z, there exist m, n ∈Z such that am + bn = c if and only if d | c. 3. a and b are coprime if and only if there exist m, n ∈Z such that am + bn = 1. 4. For all m ∈Z+, gcd(ma, mb) = m · gcd(a, b) = md. Exercise 26.1.11. (a) Use the Euclidean Algorithm to find gcd(1819, 3587). (b) Find a pair (x, y) ∈Z2 such that 1819x + 3587y = gcd(1819, 3587). Exercise 26.1.12. Let a, b ∈Z, not both 0, and m ∈Z+. Prove that gcd(ma, mb) = m · gcd(a, b). Exercise 26.1.13. Prove that if a and b are relatively prime integers then gcd(a+b, a− b) = 1 or 2, with gcd(a + b, a −b) = 2 if and only if a and b have the same parity. 167

 27. November 3 27.1. GCDs, LCMs, and Linear Combinations 27.1.1. Linear Diophantine Equations A Diophantine equation is a polynomial equation with integer coefficients, typically involving multiple variables, in which the goal is to find integer (or sometimes rational) solutions. The study of such equations forms a central area of research in Number Theory, with applications ranging from cryptography to mathematical puzzles. Diophantine equations come in many forms, varying greatly in difficulty and complexity. In this course, we will focus on a specific type of Diophantine equation called linear Diophantine equations, which involve polynomials of degree one. To motivate our exploration, let’s look at a few examples that illustrate the variety and challenges of Diophantine problems: Examples 27.1.1. 1. Find all (x, y) ∈Z2 such that y2 = x3 + 16. This is an example of a Mordell equation, a type of cubic Diophantine equation. These equations often have only a few integer solutions or none at all. For this particular equation, the only integer solutions are (0, 4) and (0, −4). 2. Find all n ∈Z that can be expressed as the sum of three cubes, i.e., ∃x, y, z ∈Z, n = x3 + y3 + z3. This is an example of a longstanding open problem in number theory. While some values of n have been resolved, finding solutions for all n remains an unsolved challenge. 3. Find all (x, y) ∈Z2 such that 6x + 9y = 27. This is a linear Diophantine equation, which we will study in detail. Unlike the previous examples, linear Diophantine equations can often be solved systematically, and we will develop techniques to find all solutions. 168

 A Diophantine equation of the form ax + by = c, where a, b, c ∈Z, is called a linear Diophantine equation in two variables. We know from B´ezout’s lemma that ∃x, y ∈Z such that ax + by = c if and only if gcd(a, b) | c. If a solution exists, we can find one such solution using the Reverse Euclidean Algorithm, as illustrated in Example 26.1.8. First, find x′, y′ ∈Z such that ax′ + by′ = gcd(a, b). For instance, in Example 26.1.8, we found that gcd(148, 40) = 4 = 148(3) + 40(−11). Since gcd(a, b) | c, we can find one solution to ax + by = c by multiplying the equation ax′ + by′ = gcd(a, b) by c gcd(a,b). For instance, if c = 36, then multiplying the previous equation by 9 gives 36 = 148(27) + 40(−99). Now that we know how to find one solution to ax+by = c, how do we find all solutions? Are there others? And if so, how many? Let’s first get a basic idea of how we can use one solution to find all solutions through the following example. Example 27.1.2. Find all integral solutions to 6x + 9y = 21. x, y ∈Z satisfy 6x + 9y = 21 if and only if 2x + 3y = 7 (dividing through by gcd(6, 9)). Thus, it suffices to find all solutions to 2x + 3y = 7. Since the numbers are small, we can guess a solution: 2(2) + 3(1) = 7. Thus, (2, 1) is one solution to the equation. Now, suppose (x, y) ∈Z2 is any solution to 2x + 3y = 7. We then have 2x + 3y = 7 = 2(2) + 3(1). This equation holds if and only if 2(x −2) = 3(1 −y). Let m = x −2 and n = 1 −y, so our equation becomes 2m = 3n. Since 2m is even (and 2 ∤3), it must be the case that 2 | n, hence n = 2k for some k ∈Z. Substituting this into our previous equation gives 2m = 6k =⇒m = 3k. Using m = x −2 and n = 1 −y, we find x = 2 + 3k and y = 1 −2k. Thus, any solution must be of the form (2 + 3k, 1 −2k) for some k ∈Z. Furthermore, we can verify that any ordered pair of this form satisfies the Diophantine equation: 2(2 + 3k) + 3(1 −2k) = 4 + 6k + 3 −6k = 7. Hence, the solution set is {(2 + 3k, 1 −2k) | k ∈Z}. 169

 We summarize the result below. The proof, which generalizes the previous example, is left for homework. Theorem 27.1.3. Let a, b, c ∈Z with a and b not both zero. If gcd(a, b) | c, then there are infinitely many integer solutions to ax + by = c. Moreover, if (x0, y0) is one solution, then all solutions are given by {(x0 + m(b/d), y0 −m(a/d)) | m ∈Z, d = gcd(a, b)}. Proof. Homework. Exercise 27.1.4. Find all integer solutions to the following linear Diophantine equations, or state why none exist. (a) 123x + 45y = 17 (b) 123x + 45y = 18 27.1.2. Least Common Multiples We now discuss the concept of the least common multiple, which serves as a natural counterpart to the greatest common divisor. Definition. Let a, b, c ∈Z ∖{0}. We say that c is a common multiple of a and b if a | c and b | c. Furthermore, c is called the least common multiple of a and b, denoted lcm[a, b], if c > 0 and c is the smallest of all positive common multiples of a and b. The following theorem establishes a key property of the least common multiple. Theorem 27.1.5. Let a, b ∈Z, not both zero. For any n ∈Z, we have lcm[a, b] | n if and only if a | n and b | n. Proof. (⇒): Suppose lcm[a, b] | n. Since a | lcm[a, b] and b | lcm[a, b], the transitivity of divisibility implies that a | n and b | n. Thus, n is a common multiple of a and b. (⇐): Suppose a | n and b | n. By the division algorithm, there exist q, r ∈Z with 0 ≤r < lcm[a, b] such that n = q · lcm[a, b] + r. Since a | n and a | lcm[a, b], we have a | (n −q · lcm[a, b]), implying a | r by the properties of divisibility. A similar argument shows that b | r. 170

 Since 0 ≤r < lcm[a, b] and r is a common multiple of a and b, it follows that r = 0. Hence, lcm[a, b] | n. The following corollaries capture additional useful properties of the least common multiple. Their proofs are left as exercises. Corollaries 27.1.6. Let a, b ∈Z, not both zero. Then: 1. lcm[a, b] = |b| if and only if a | b. 2. For any m ∈Z+, lcm[ma, mb] = m · lcm[a, b]. Exercise 27.1.7. Prove the previous corollaries. The next theorem establishes a fundamental relationship between the greatest common divisor and the least common multiple. Theorem 27.1.8 (GCD-LCM Theorem). For any positive integers a and b, we have gcd(a, b) · lcm[a, b] = ab. Proof. Homework Note. To compute the least common multiple of two integers, no new algorithm is required. Once the greatest common divisor is known, the least common multiple can be determined directly using the GCD-LCM relationship. 27.2. Prime Factorizations Prime numbers are often referred to as the building blocks of the integers. One of the most significant properties of integers is that every positive integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of prime numbers in exactly one way, up to the order of the factors. This result is known as the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic. The decomposition of integers into their prime factors is a powerful tool in mathematics, with applications ranging from simplifying fractions to enabling secure encryption methods. The key result needed to establish this theorem is derived from B´ezout’s Lemma. Theorem 27.2.1 (Euclid’s Lemma). Let a, b, c ∈Z. If a and b are relatively prime (i.e., gcd(a, b) = 1) and a | bc, then a | c. 171

 Proof. Let a, b, c ∈Z such that gcd(a, b) = 1 and a | bc. Since gcd(a, b) = 1, B´ezout’s Lemma guarantees the existence of integers m, n ∈Z such that am + bn = 1. Fix such values of m and n. Since a | bc, there exists some k ∈Z such that bc = ak. Multiplying both sides of am + bn = 1 by c gives amc + bnc = c. Substituting bc = ak into the equation, we get c = amc + akn = a(mc + kn). Thus, a | c, as required. The following corollary is a special case of Euclid’s Lemma when a is a prime number. Corollary 27.2.2. Let p, b, c ∈Z with p prime. If p | bc, then p | b or p | c. 172

 28. November 5 28.1. Prime Factorizations We now have the necessary tools to establish the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic. Theorem 28.1.1 (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic). Every integer n > 1 can be uniquely written as a product of prime numbers, up to the order of the prime factors. In other words, if n = p1 · p2 · · · pr = q1 · q2 · · · qs for prime numbers pi and qj such that p1 ≤p2 ≤· · · ≤pr and q1 ≤q2 ≤· · · ≤qs, then r = s and pi = qi for each i ∈[r]. Proof. Existence – This has already been established in Theorem 11.1.7. Uniqueness – Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that there exists a positive integer n such that n > 1 and n has two distinct prime factorizations. Let n0 be the smallest such integer, according to the well-ordering property. Then, there exist positive integers k, ℓ∈Z+ and prime numbers pi and qj for 1 ≤i ≤k and 1 ≤j ≤ℓsuch that n0 = k Y i=1 pi = ℓY j=1 qj. We consider two cases: • Case 1: k = 1 or ℓ= 1. Without loss of generality, assume k = 1. Then n0 = p1 = ℓY j=1 qj. Since p1 is prime, it must be that ℓ= 1 and hence n0 = p1 = q1. This contradicts the assumption that the prime factorizations were distinct. 173

 • Case 2: k, ℓ≥2. Since p1 | n0, it follows that p1 | Qℓ j=1 qj. Because p1 is prime, the corollary to Euclid’s Lemma implies that there exists some j ∈[ℓ] such that p1 | qj. By relabeling the qj’s if necessary, we may assume that p1 | q1. This implies that q1 = p1 since q1 is prime. Then n0 p1 is an integer greater than 1, and n0 p1 = k Y i=2 pi = ℓY j=2 qj. Since k, ℓ≥2, this shows that n0 p1 has two distinct prime factorizations. But n0 p1 < n0, contradicting the assumption that n0 was the smallest integer greater than 1 with two distinct prime factorizations. Since these are the only two cases and they both lead to contradictions, we conclude that every integer n > 1 can be written uniquely as a product of primes. Examples 28.1.2. 1. 240 = 2 · 2 · 2 · 2 · 3 · 5 = 24 · 3 · 5. Moreover, this is the only way to factor 240 into a product of prime numbers. Viewing the prime numbers as the building blocks, we see that 240 is composed of 4 copies of 2, 1 copy of 3, and 1 copy of 5. 2. 289 = 17 · 17 = 172 3. 1001 = 7 · 11 · 13 Our next result establishes a fact that we have been assuming implicitly for some time. Corollary 28.1.3 (Infinitude of Primes). There are infinitely many prime numbers. Proof. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that there are only finitely many prime numbers, say n primes for some n ∈Z+. List these primes as p1, p2, . . . , pn. Define P ∈N to be one more than the product of these primes, i.e., P = n Y i=1 pi ! + 1 = p1p2 · · · pn + 1. Since P > 1, the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic implies that P has at least one prime divisor. Given that there are only finitely many primes, it follows that pj | P for some j ∈{1, 2, . . . , n}. Thus, we can write P = pjk for some k ∈Z. 174

 However, pj also divides nQ i=1 pi (as pj is one of the factors in the product), so we can express nQ i=1 pi = pjℓfor some ℓ∈Z. Consequently, we have 1 = P − n Y i=1 pi = pj(k −ℓ), which implies pj | 1. This is a contradiction, as no prime number divides 1. Therefore, our original assumption must be false, and there are indeed infinitely many prime numbers. Note. This proof shows that if p1, . . . , pn are the first n prime numbers, then the next prime could be as large as P = n Y i=1 pi ! + 1. However, this is a significant overestimate. For example, this method would imply that p10 ≤223092871, while in reality, p10 = 29. 28.1.1. Divisors Let P be the set of prime numbers. For each p ∈P and n ∈Z+, define vp(n) = max{a ∈N | pa divides n} as the largest power of p dividing n. If a, b, and n are positive integers such that n = ab, then for all p ∈P, we have vp(n) = vp(a) + vp(b). Hence, vp(a) ≤vp(n). This implies that if n has a prime factorization n = pn1 1 pn2 2 · · · pnk k , then we can express a as a = pa1 1 pa2 2 · · · pak k , for some ai where 0 ≤ai ≤ni for each 1 ≤i ≤k. (Note that we allow ai = 0 for any or all values of i.) Since any positive divisor must be of this form, and any integer of this form is indeed a divisor of n, we have now classified all divisors of n. This allows us to count the number of divisors of n. • For an arbitrary divisor a of n, there are ni + 1 possible values for vpi(a). • Since there are k distinct primes in the prime factorization of n, the total number of divisors of n is given by kQ i=1 (ni + 1). 175

 GCDs and LCMs Revisited We can use the above ideas to provide an alternative characterization of GCDs and LCMs. Theorem 28.1.4. Let a, b ∈Z be greater than 1. Further, let {p1, . . . , pn} be the set of all prime factors of either a or b. Then we can express a and b as a = n Y i=1 pai i and b = n Y i=1 pbi i , where ai ≥0 and bi ≥0 for 1 ≤i ≤n. Then gcd(a, b) = n Y i=1 pmin{ai,bi} i , lcm[a, b] = n Y i=1 pmax{ai,bi} i . Proof. Let d = gcd(a, b). For each 1 ≤i ≤n, we have vpi(d) ≤ai and vpi(d) ≤bi. Thus, vpi(d) ≤min{ai, bi}. Moreover, nQ i=1 pmin{ai,bi} i divides a, as seen from a = n Y i=1 pmin{ai,bi} i ! n Y i=1 pai−min{ai,bi} i ! . Similarly, nQ i=1 pmin{ai,bi} i divides b. Since d is the greatest common divisor of a and b, we must have vpi(d) = min{ai, bi} for all i. Therefore, d = nQ i=1 pmin{ai,bi} i . A similar argument establishes the result for the least common multiple. Example 28.1.5. Consider the integers 720 and 700. We have 720 = 24 · 32 · 51 · 70, 700 = 22 · 30 · 52 · 71, gcd(720, 700) = 22 · 30 · 51 · 70, lcm[720, 700] = 24 · 32 · 52 · 71. Hence, gcd(720, 700) = 20 and lcm(720, 700) = 25200. The GCD-LCM Theorem 27.1.8 follows immediately from the previous theorem. 176

 Corollary 28.1.6 (GCD-LCM Theorem). For all a, b ∈Z+, we have ab = gcd(a, b) · lcm[a, b]. Exercise 28.1.7. (a) Prove that a positive integer n is a perfect square if and only if the exponent of each prime factor of n is even. (b) Prove that if a and b are coprime positive integers and their product is a perfect square, then a and b are themselves perfect squares. (c) Prove that if a and b are positive integers and ab is a perfect square, then a = dm2 and b = dn2 where d = gcd(a, b), for some coprime integers m and n. (d) Reprove the irrationality of √ 2 in the following way: • Assume for the sake of contradiction that √ 2 = a b where a, b ∈Z+ are coprime. Use part (a) to arrive at a contradiction. Exercise 28.1.8. Use the fundamental theorem of arithmetic to prove that 171/3 is irrational. 28.2. Modular Arithmetic Recall: For m ∈Z+ and a, b ∈Z, we say that a is congruent to b modulo m, denoted a ≡b (mod m), if and only if m | (a−b). We proved in Theorem 18.1.3 that congruence modulo m is an equivalence relation. The set of equivalence classes (often called congruence classes in this context) is denoted by Z/mZ = {[a]m | a ∈Z}. In computer science, “mod” is often treated as an operation that takes an integer a as input and returns the remainder r when a is divided by m. As a relation, this means a ≡r (mod m) (equivalently, [a]m = [r]m). This interpretation can be justified by the following theorem. Theorem 28.2.1. For all a, b ∈Z and all m ∈Z+, we have a ≡b (mod m) ⇐⇒a and b have the same remainder when divided by m. Proof. Let a, b ∈Z and m ∈Z+. By the Division Algorithm, there exist unique integers q1, r1, q2, r2 ∈Z such that a = mq1 + r1 and b = mq2 + r2, 177

 where 0 ≤r1 < m and 0 ≤r2 < m. We will show that a ≡b (mod m) if and only if r1 = r2. (⇒): Suppose a ≡b (mod m). Then m | (a −b), so there exists k ∈Z such that a −b = mk. Substituting our expressions for a and b, we get mk = m(q1 −q2) + (r1 −r2). Solving for r1 −r2 gives r1 −r2 = m(k −(q1 −q2)), which shows that m | (r1 −r2). Since 0 ≤r1, r2 < m, we have −m < r1 −r2 < m, and the only multiple of m in this range is 0. Hence r1 −r2 = 0, so r1 = r2. (⇐): Suppose r1 = r2. Then a −b = m(q1 −q2), which implies m | (a −b), and therefore a ≡b (mod m). The following corollary is immediate. Corollary 28.2.2. Let m ∈Z+. Every integer is congruent to exactly one element of the set {0, 1, . . . , m −1} modulo m. Equivalently, Z/mZ = {[0]m, [1]m, . . . , [m −1]m}. The set {0, 1, . . . , m−1} is an example of what we call a complete set of residues modulo m. Definition. For m ∈Z+, a set {a1, . . . , am} ⊂Z is called a complete set of residues modulo m if every integer is congruent to exactly one element of {a1, . . . , am} modulo m. Examples 28.2.3. There are infinitely many complete sets of residues modulo m, but some are more commonly used than others. • Least Nonnegative Residues modulo m: {0, 1, . . . , m −1}. • Least Positive Residues modulo m: {1, 2, . . . , m}. • Least Absolute Residues modulo m: ▶If m is odd: {0, 1, −1, 2, −2, . . . , m−1 2 , −m−1 2 }. ▶If m is even: {0, 1, −1, 2, −2, . . . , m−2 2 , −m−2 2 , m 2 }. 178

Linear Diophantine Equations A Diophantine equation is a polynomial equation with integer coefficients, typically involving multiple variables, in which the goal is to find integer (or sometimes rational) solutions. The study of such equations forms a central area of research in Number Theory, with applications ranging from cryptography to mathematical puzzles. Diophantine equations come in many forms, varying greatly in difficulty and complexity. In this course, we will focus on a specific type of Diophantine equation called linear Diophantine equations, which involve polynomials of degree one. To motivate our exploration, let’s look at a few examples that illustrate the variety and challenges of Diophantine problems: Examples 27.1.1. 1. Find all (x, y) ∈Z2 such that y2 = x3 + 16. This is an example of a Mordell equation, a type of cubic Diophantine equation. These equations often have only a few integer solutions or none at all. For this particular equation, the only integer solutions are (0, 4) and (0, −4). 2. Find all n ∈Z that can be expressed as the sum of three cubes, i.e., ∃x, y, z ∈Z, n = x3 + y3 + z3. This is an example of a longstanding open problem in number theory. While some values of n have been resolved, finding solutions for all n remains an unsolved challenge. 3. Find all (x, y) ∈Z2 such that 6x + 9y = 27. This is a linear Diophantine equation, which we will study in detail. Unlike the previous examples, linear Diophantine equations can often be solved systematically, and we will develop techniques to find all solutions. 168

 A Diophantine equation of the form ax + by = c, where a, b, c ∈Z, is called a linear Diophantine equation in two variables. We know from B´ezout’s lemma that ∃x, y ∈Z such that ax + by = c if and only if gcd(a, b) | c. If a solution exists, we can find one such solution using the Reverse Euclidean Algorithm, as illustrated in Example 26.1.8. First, find x′, y′ ∈Z such that ax′ + by′ = gcd(a, b). For instance, in Example 26.1.8, we found that gcd(148, 40) = 4 = 148(3) + 40(−11). Since gcd(a, b) | c, we can find one solution to ax + by = c by multiplying the equation ax′ + by′ = gcd(a, b) by c gcd(a,b). For instance, if c = 36, then multiplying the previous equation by 9 gives 36 = 148(27) + 40(−99). Now that we know how to find one solution to ax+by = c, how do we find all solutions? Are there others? And if so, how many? Let’s first get a basic idea of how we can use one solution to find all solutions through the following example. Example 27.1.2. Find all integral solutions to 6x + 9y = 21. x, y ∈Z satisfy 6x + 9y = 21 if and only if 2x + 3y = 7 (dividing through by gcd(6, 9)). Thus, it suffices to find all solutions to 2x + 3y = 7. Since the numbers are small, we can guess a solution: 2(2) + 3(1) = 7. Thus, (2, 1) is one solution to the equation. Now, suppose (x, y) ∈Z2 is any solution to 2x + 3y = 7. We then have 2x + 3y = 7 = 2(2) + 3(1). This equation holds if and only if 2(x −2) = 3(1 −y). Let m = x −2 and n = 1 −y, so our equation becomes 2m = 3n. Since 2m is even (and 2 ∤3), it must be the case that 2 | n, hence n = 2k for some k ∈Z. Substituting this into our previous equation gives 2m = 6k =⇒m = 3k. Using m = x −2 and n = 1 −y, we find x = 2 + 3k and y = 1 −2k. Thus, any solution must be of the form (2 + 3k, 1 −2k) for some k ∈Z. Furthermore, we can verify that any ordered pair of this form satisfies the Diophantine equation: 2(2 + 3k) + 3(1 −2k) = 4 + 6k + 3 −6k = 7. Hence, the solution set is {(2 + 3k, 1 −2k) | k ∈Z}. 169

 We summarize the result below. The proof, which generalizes the previous example, is left for homework. Theorem 27.1.3. Let a, b, c ∈Z with a and b not both zero. If gcd(a, b) | c, then there are infinitely many integer solutions to ax + by = c. Moreover, if (x0, y0) is one solution, then all solutions are given by {(x0 + m(b/d), y0 −m(a/d)) | m ∈Z, d = gcd(a, b)}. Proof. Homework. Exercise 27.1.4. Find all integer solutions to the following linear Diophantine equations, or state why none exist. (a) 123x + 45y = 17 (b) 123x + 45y = 18 27.1.2. Least Common Multiples We now discuss the concept of the least common multiple, which serves as a natural counterpart to the greatest common divisor. Definition. Let a, b, c ∈Z ∖{0}. We say that c is a common multiple of a and b if a | c and b | c. Furthermore, c is called the least common multiple of a and b, denoted lcm[a, b], if c > 0 and c is the smallest of all positive common multiples of a and b. The following theorem establishes a key property of the least common multiple. Theorem 27.1.5. Let a, b ∈Z, not both zero. For any n ∈Z, we have lcm[a, b] | n if and only if a | n and b | n. Proof. (⇒): Suppose lcm[a, b] | n. Since a | lcm[a, b] and b | lcm[a, b], the transitivity of divisibility implies that a | n and b | n. Thus, n is a common multiple of a and b. (⇐): Suppose a | n and b | n. By the division algorithm, there exist q, r ∈Z with 0 ≤r < lcm[a, b] such that n = q · lcm[a, b] + r. Since a | n and a | lcm[a, b], we have a | (n −q · lcm[a, b]), implying a | r by the properties of divisibility. A similar argument shows that b | r. 170

 Since 0 ≤r < lcm[a, b] and r is a common multiple of a and b, it follows that r = 0. Hence, lcm[a, b] | n. The following corollaries capture additional useful properties of the least common multiple. Their proofs are left as exercises. Corollaries 27.1.6. Let a, b ∈Z, not both zero. Then: 1. lcm[a, b] = |b| if and only if a | b. 2. For any m ∈Z+, lcm[ma, mb] = m · lcm[a, b]. Exercise 27.1.7. Prove the previous corollaries. The next theorem establishes a fundamental relationship between the greatest common divisor and the least common multiple. Theorem 27.1.8 (GCD-LCM Theorem). For any positive integers a and b, we have gcd(a, b) · lcm[a, b] = ab. Proof. Homework Note. To compute the least common multiple of two integers, no new algorithm is required. Once the greatest common divisor is known, the least common multiple can be determined directly using the GCD-LCM relationship. 27.2. Prime Factorizations Prime numbers are often referred to as the building blocks of the integers. One of the most significant properties of integers is that every positive integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of prime numbers in exactly one way, up to the order of the factors. This result is known as the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic. The decomposition of integers into their prime factors is a powerful tool in mathematics, with applications ranging from simplifying fractions to enabling secure encryption methods. The key result needed to establish this theorem is derived from B´ezout’s Lemma. Theorem 27.2.1 (Euclid’s Lemma). Let a, b, c ∈Z. If a and b are relatively prime (i.e., gcd(a, b) = 1) and a | bc, then a | c. 171

 Proof. Let a, b, c ∈Z such that gcd(a, b) = 1 and a | bc. Since gcd(a, b) = 1, B´ezout’s Lemma guarantees the existence of integers m, n ∈Z such that am + bn = 1. Fix such values of m and n. Since a | bc, there exists some k ∈Z such that bc = ak. Multiplying both sides of am + bn = 1 by c gives amc + bnc = c. Substituting bc = ak into the equation, we get c = amc + akn = a(mc + kn). Thus, a | c, as required. The following corollary is a special case of Euclid’s Lemma when a is a prime number. Corollary 27.2.2. Let p, b, c ∈Z with p prime. If p | bc, then p | b or p | c. 172

 28. November 5 28.1. Prime Factorizations We now have the necessary tools to establish the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic. Theorem 28.1.1 (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic). Every integer n > 1 can be uniquely written as a product of prime numbers, up to the order of the prime factors. In other words, if n = p1 · p2 · · · pr = q1 · q2 · · · qs for prime numbers pi and qj such that p1 ≤p2 ≤· · · ≤pr and q1 ≤q2 ≤· · · ≤qs, then r = s and pi = qi for each i ∈[r]. Proof. Existence – This has already been established in Theorem 11.1.7. Uniqueness – Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that there exists a positive integer n such that n > 1 and n has two distinct prime factorizations. Let n0 be the smallest such integer, according to the well-ordering property. Then, there exist positive integers k, ℓ∈Z+ and prime numbers pi and qj for 1 ≤i ≤k and 1 ≤j ≤ℓsuch that n0 = k Y i=1 pi = ℓY j=1 qj. We consider two cases: • Case 1: k = 1 or ℓ= 1. Without loss of generality, assume k = 1. Then n0 = p1 = ℓY j=1 qj. Since p1 is prime, it must be that ℓ= 1 and hence n0 = p1 = q1. This contradicts the assumption that the prime factorizations were distinct. 173

 • Case 2: k, ℓ≥2. Since p1 | n0, it follows that p1 | Qℓ j=1 qj. Because p1 is prime, the corollary to Euclid’s Lemma implies that there exists some j ∈[ℓ] such that p1 | qj. By relabeling the qj’s if necessary, we may assume that p1 | q1. This implies that q1 = p1 since q1 is prime. Then n0 p1 is an integer greater than 1, and n0 p1 = k Y i=2 pi = ℓY j=2 qj. Since k, ℓ≥2, this shows that n0 p1 has two distinct prime factorizations. But n0 p1 < n0, contradicting the assumption that n0 was the smallest integer greater than 1 with two distinct prime factorizations. Since these are the only two cases and they both lead to contradictions, we conclude that every integer n > 1 can be written uniquely as a product of primes. Examples 28.1.2. 1. 240 = 2 · 2 · 2 · 2 · 3 · 5 = 24 · 3 · 5. Moreover, this is the only way to factor 240 into a product of prime numbers. Viewing the prime numbers as the building blocks, we see that 240 is composed of 4 copies of 2, 1 copy of 3, and 1 copy of 5. 2. 289 = 17 · 17 = 172 3. 1001 = 7 · 11 · 13 Our next result establishes a fact that we have been assuming implicitly for some time. Corollary 28.1.3 (Infinitude of Primes). There are infinitely many prime numbers. Proof. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that there are only finitely many prime numbers, say n primes for some n ∈Z+. List these primes as p1, p2, . . . , pn. Define P ∈N to be one more than the product of these primes, i.e., P = n Y i=1 pi ! + 1 = p1p2 · · · pn + 1. Since P > 1, the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic implies that P has at least one prime divisor. Given that there are only finitely many primes, it follows that pj | P for some j ∈{1, 2, . . . , n}. Thus, we can write P = pjk for some k ∈Z. 174

 However, pj also divides nQ i=1 pi (as pj is one of the factors in the product), so we can express nQ i=1 pi = pjℓfor some ℓ∈Z. Consequently, we have 1 = P − n Y i=1 pi = pj(k −ℓ), which implies pj | 1. This is a contradiction, as no prime number divides 1. Therefore, our original assumption must be false, and there are indeed infinitely many prime numbers. Note. This proof shows that if p1, . . . , pn are the first n prime numbers, then the next prime could be as large as P = n Y i=1 pi ! + 1. However, this is a significant overestimate. For example, this method would imply that p10 ≤223092871, while in reality, p10 = 29. 28.1.1. Divisors Let P be the set of prime numbers. For each p ∈P and n ∈Z+, define vp(n) = max{a ∈N | pa divides n} as the largest power of p dividing n. If a, b, and n are positive integers such that n = ab, then for all p ∈P, we have vp(n) = vp(a) + vp(b). Hence, vp(a) ≤vp(n). This implies that if n has a prime factorization n = pn1 1 pn2 2 · · · pnk k , then we can express a as a = pa1 1 pa2 2 · · · pak k , for some ai where 0 ≤ai ≤ni for each 1 ≤i ≤k. (Note that we allow ai = 0 for any or all values of i.) Since any positive divisor must be of this form, and any integer of this form is indeed a divisor of n, we have now classified all divisors of n. This allows us to count the number of divisors of n. • For an arbitrary divisor a of n, there are ni + 1 possible values for vpi(a). • Since there are k distinct primes in the prime factorization of n, the total number of divisors of n is given by kQ i=1 (ni + 1). 175

 GCDs and LCMs Revisited We can use the above ideas to provide an alternative characterization of GCDs and LCMs. Theorem 28.1.4. Let a, b ∈Z be greater than 1. Further, let {p1, . . . , pn} be the set of all prime factors of either a or b. Then we can express a and b as a = n Y i=1 pai i and b = n Y i=1 pbi i , where ai ≥0 and bi ≥0 for 1 ≤i ≤n. Then gcd(a, b) = n Y i=1 pmin{ai,bi} i , lcm[a, b] = n Y i=1 pmax{ai,bi} i . Proof. Let d = gcd(a, b). For each 1 ≤i ≤n, we have vpi(d) ≤ai and vpi(d) ≤bi. Thus, vpi(d) ≤min{ai, bi}. Moreover, nQ i=1 pmin{ai,bi} i divides a, as seen from a = n Y i=1 pmin{ai,bi} i ! n Y i=1 pai−min{ai,bi} i ! . Similarly, nQ i=1 pmin{ai,bi} i divides b. Since d is the greatest common divisor of a and b, we must have vpi(d) = min{ai, bi} for all i. Therefore, d = nQ i=1 pmin{ai,bi} i . A similar argument establishes the result for the least common multiple. Example 28.1.5. Consider the integers 720 and 700. We have 720 = 24 · 32 · 51 · 70, 700 = 22 · 30 · 52 · 71, gcd(720, 700) = 22 · 30 · 51 · 70, lcm[720, 700] = 24 · 32 · 52 · 71. Hence, gcd(720, 700) = 20 and lcm(720, 700) = 25200. The GCD-LCM Theorem 27.1.8 follows immediately from the previous theorem. 176

 Corollary 28.1.6 (GCD-LCM Theorem). For all a, b ∈Z+, we have ab = gcd(a, b) · lcm[a, b]. Exercise 28.1.7. (a) Prove that a positive integer n is a perfect square if and only if the exponent of each prime factor of n is even. (b) Prove that if a and b are coprime positive integers and their product is a perfect square, then a and b are themselves perfect squares. (c) Prove that if a and b are positive integers and ab is a perfect square, then a = dm2 and b = dn2 where d = gcd(a, b), for some coprime integers m and n. (d) Reprove the irrationality of √ 2 in the following way: • Assume for the sake of contradiction that √ 2 = a b where a, b ∈Z+ are coprime. Use part (a) to arrive at a contradiction. Exercise 28.1.8. Use the fundamental theorem of arithmetic to prove that 171/3 is irrational. 28.2. Modular Arithmetic Recall: For m ∈Z+ and a, b ∈Z, we say that a is congruent to b modulo m, denoted a ≡b (mod m), if and only if m | (a−b). We proved in Theorem 18.1.3 that congruence modulo m is an equivalence relation. The set of equivalence classes (often called congruence classes in this context) is denoted by Z/mZ = {[a]m | a ∈Z}. In computer science, “mod” is often treated as an operation that takes an integer a as input and returns the remainder r when a is divided by m. As a relation, this means a ≡r (mod m) (equivalently, [a]m = [r]m). This interpretation can be justified by the following theorem. Theorem 28.2.1. For all a, b ∈Z and all m ∈Z+, we have a ≡b (mod m) ⇐⇒a and b have the same remainder when divided by m. Proof. Let a, b ∈Z and m ∈Z+. By the Division Algorithm, there exist unique integers q1, r1, q2, r2 ∈Z such that a = mq1 + r1 and b = mq2 + r2, 177

 where 0 ≤r1 < m and 0 ≤r2 < m. We will show that a ≡b (mod m) if and only if r1 = r2. (⇒): Suppose a ≡b (mod m). Then m | (a −b), so there exists k ∈Z such that a −b = mk. Substituting our expressions for a and b, we get mk = m(q1 −q2) + (r1 −r2). Solving for r1 −r2 gives r1 −r2 = m(k −(q1 −q2)), which shows that m | (r1 −r2). Since 0 ≤r1, r2 < m, we have −m < r1 −r2 < m, and the only multiple of m in this range is 0. Hence r1 −r2 = 0, so r1 = r2. (⇐): Suppose r1 = r2. Then a −b = m(q1 −q2), which implies m | (a −b), and therefore a ≡b (mod m). The following corollary is immediate. Corollary 28.2.2. Let m ∈Z+. Every integer is congruent to exactly one element of the set {0, 1, . . . , m −1} modulo m. Equivalently, Z/mZ = {[0]m, [1]m, . . . , [m −1]m}. The set {0, 1, . . . , m−1} is an example of what we call a complete set of residues modulo m. Definition. For m ∈Z+, a set {a1, . . . , am} ⊂Z is called a complete set of residues modulo m if every integer is congruent to exactly one element of {a1, . . . , am} modulo m. Examples 28.2.3. There are infinitely many complete sets of residues modulo m, but some are more commonly used than others. • Least Nonnegative Residues modulo m: {0, 1, . . . , m −1}. • Least Positive Residues modulo m: {1, 2, . . . , m}. • Least Absolute Residues modulo m: ▶If m is odd: {0, 1, −1, 2, −2, . . . , m−1 2 , −m−1 2 }. ▶If m is even: {0, 1, −1, 2, −2, . . . , m−2 2 , −m−2 2 , m 2 }. 178

Let A be the set of all possible meals that can be ordered at a restaurant where each meal consists of one appetizer, one entr´ee, and one dessert. Define A1 = the set of possible appetizers, A2 = the set of possible entr´ees, A3 = the set of possible desserts. 203

 We can view A as A = A1 × A2 × A3. If |A1|= 5, |A2|= 10, and |A3|= 6, then by the Rule of Product, |A|= 5 · 10 · 6 = 300. To formally prove this theorem, we can rely on results already discussed in the section on cardinality. Sketch of Proof. If Ai = ∅for any i, then |A|= 0 and Qn i=1|Ai|= 0. Otherwise, assume each Ai is nonempty and proceed by induction on n ∈Z+. The base case n = 1 is trivial, and for n = 2, we have shown that if |A1|= k and |A2|= ℓ, then |A1 ×A2|= kℓ. Theorem 32.2.8 (Rule of Product, Reformulated). Suppose that the elements of a set are constructed by making a sequence of k choices such that: (i) The i-th choice can be made in ri ways, independently of previous choices. (ii) Each element in the set is uniquely determined by this sequence of choices. Then the total number of elements in the set is given by Qk i=1 ri. Returning to our restaurant example, each possible meal results from a sequence of three independent choices: there are 5 choices for an appetizer, 10 choices for an entr´ee (regardless of the appetizer), and 6 choices for a dessert (regardless of prior selections). Thus, there are 5·10·6 = 300 possible meals, each uniquely determined by one sequence of choices. A Combined Example Using Rules of Sum and Product Example 32.2.9. How many strings of lowercase English letters are there of length 4 or less (including the empty string)? Let A be the set of all such strings. We can partition A by length: {A0, A1, A2, A3, A4}, where A0 = the set of strings of length 0, A1 = the set of strings of length 1, A2 = the set of strings of length 2, A3 = the set of strings of length 3, A4 = the set of strings of length 4. 204

By the Rule of Product, there are 52·51 ways to select an ordered pair of cards.  33. November 17 33.1. Basic Counting Principles 33.1.1. The Principle of Double Counting If we count the size of a set in two different ways, then both expressions for the cardinality of the set must be equal. This principle, known as double counting, often reveals interesting combinatorial identities. Example 33.1.1 (The Handshake Lemma). Suppose there are n people at a party, and everyone shakes hands with everyone else exactly once. How many handshakes occur in total? • Method 1: Each of the n people shakes hands with n −1 others. Counting all handshakes in this way gives n(n −1), but each handshake is counted twice (once for each participant). Thus, we divide by 2 to obtain the total number of unique handshakes: n(n −1) 2 . • Method 2: Number the n people from 1 to n. To avoid double counting, consider only the handshakes each person makes with those numbered lower than themselves. Let Ai denote the set of handshakes made by person i with people numbered below i. Since person i has i −1 such handshakes, we find |A|= n X i=1 |Ai|= n X i=1 (i −1) = n−1 X j=1 j. Since both expressions describe the total number of handshakes, they must be equal. Therefore, n(n −1) 2 = n−1 X j=1 j. This equality coincides with the formula for the sum of the first n −1 positive integers, which we previously proved by induction. The argument above illustrates a counting in two ways proof. We will encounter additional examples of this technique throughout the remainder of these notes. 209

 We now wish to discuss some additional combinatorial methods. Most counting problems that we encounter fall into one of four categories: arrangements without repetition, arrangements with repetition, selections without repetition, and selections with repetition. 33.2. Arrangements and Selections 33.2.1. Ordered Arrangements/Permutations Definition. Let n, k ∈N with n ≥k, and let X be a set with |X|= n. A karrangement of X is an injection f : [k] →X. Arrangements appear frequently in combinatorics, and several equivalent descriptions are used in practice. For example, a string of distinct letters is an arrangement: the positions in the string form the domain, and the chosen letters form the codomain. M A T H is a 4-arrangement of the alphabet (a string of length 4 with no repeated letters). Similarly, a finite sequence or ordered n-tuple with no repeated entries is an arrangement. The 5-tuple (1, 2, 3, 5, 8) is a 5-arrangement. Counting the number of k-arrangements of a set of size n is a straightforward application of the Rule of Product. Theorem 33.2.1. Let n, k ∈Z+ with n ≥k, and let X be a set with |X|= n. Then the number of k-arrangements from X is given by n · (n −1) · · · (n −k + 1) = k−1 Y i=0 (n −i) = n! (n −k)!. Proof. Without loss of generality, we may assume X = [n]. Let P(n, k) denote the set of k-arrangements of [n]. We construct an arbitrary f ∈P(n, k) through the following k-step procedure: • Choose f(1): there are n options. • Choose f(2), distinct from f(1): there are n −1 options. • In general, at step i, there are n −(i −1) options for f(i). 210

 After step k, the function f is completely determined. Each arrangement is produced by exactly one such sequence of choices, so by the Rule of Product, |P(n, k)|= k Y i=1 (n −(i −1)) = k−1 Y i=0 (n −i) = n! (n −k)!. We illustrate with a simple example. Example 33.2.2. Out of a group of 20 contestants, we must select first, second, and third place. How many possible outcomes are there? Let X be the set of contestants. This is equivalent to counting the number of injections f : [3] ,→X, since the three places must be assigned to three distinct contestants. Alternatively, we can view this as filling three ordered positions: 1st 2nd 3rd By the Rule of Product, there are 20 choices for 1st, 19 choices for 2nd, 18 choices for 3rd. 20 1st 19 2nd 18 3rd Thus the total number of possible outcomes is 20 · 19 · 18 = 20! 17! = 6840 . The most important special case is when k = n, which yields the notion of a permutation. Definition. Let n ∈Z+ and let X be a finite set with |X|= n. A permutation of X is a bijection f : [n] →X. Equivalently, a permutation is a string or ordered n-tuple containing each element of X exactly once. Notation: Given a set X, we denote the set of permutations of X by Sym(X). When X = [n], we write Sn. 211

We will prove the existence portion later, when we study induction. For now, we prove the uniqueness portion. Uniqueness. Let q1, q2, r1, r2 ∈Z satisfy a = bq1 + r1 = bq2 + r2, 0 ≤r1 < b, 0 ≤r2 < b. From the inequalities, we obtain −b < −r2 ≤0. Adding this to 0 ≤r1 < b gives −b < r1 −r2 < b. Since bq1 + r1 = bq2 + r2, it follows that r1 −r2 = b(q2 −q1). Thus r1 −r2 is a multiple of b. Dividing the inequality −b < r1 −r2 < b by b yields −1 < q2 −q1 < 1. Because q2 −q1 ∈Z, we must have q2 −q1 = 0, so q1 = q2. Substituting back gives r1 −r2 = b(q2 −q1) = 0, hence r1 = r2. Clearly state any assumptions or conditions needed for your proof. For example, if you assume that a function is continuous or that a set is non-empty, make sure to state this explicitly at the beginning of the proof. 47

 • Check Your Proof’s Structure. Ensure that your proof has a clear structure with a defined start, body, and conclusion. The proof should lead logically from the hypotheses to the conclusion, and each part of the proof should contribute to this progression. • Include All Steps. Don’t skip steps when writing your proofs. It is important for your reader to follow your work. Even if a step seems obvious to you, include it. Your intended audience should be able to completely understand and verify your proof. • Explain Why Steps Are Valid. Each step should be correct and clearly justified. If a step relies on a theorem or lemma, briefly mention this and explain why the application is valid. • Define New Variables or Notation. When introducing new variables or notation, be clear. For example, instead of writing “Since n is even, n = 2m,” write “Since n is even, there exists an integer m such that n = 2m.” • Use First Person Plural. Proofs should be written in the first person plural using the pronoun “we.” For instance, “We then have. . . ” or “We now see that. . . ” • Use Complete Sentences. Good mathematical writing uses complete sentences. Your proof should be a short work of mathematical prose, with correct grammar, sentence structure, and punctuation. Students writing proofs for the first time often feel like they’re not allowed to use words because they’re “not math.” A page full of just a series of mathematical symbols might look impressive, but it usually makes your argument harder to follow. Words (and even diagrams) are often necessary to explain your arguments. Notation should be used in moderation to improve readability and precision. • Indicate Directions in Biconditional Proofs. When proving biconditional claims, clearly indicate which direction of the proposition you are proving. For instance, if you are proving P ↔Q, your proof should have two parts: (⇒): Prove P →Q (⇐): Prove Q →P • Use Appropriate Notation. Use the appropriate notation for the context. For example, instead of writing “Let a ∈X,” it is better to write “Let x ∈X” or “Let a ∈A.” Avoid confusing notations like “Let X ∈A × B.” Instead, write “Let (a, b) ∈A × B.” • Revise and Refine. After completing a proof, review it to check for clarity and accuracy. Look for any parts that might be confusing or ambiguous and revise them. Rewriting parts of the proof in simpler terms can also help clarify your arguments. 48

instruction: State Principle of Mathematical Induction.
output: Let P(n) be a statement about n ∈N. If 1. P(0) is true, and 2. for all k ∈N, if P(k) is true then P(k + 1) is true, then P(n) is true for all n ∈N. As an analogy, consider an infinite line of equally spaced dominoes representing the natural numbers, as shown below. The assumptions of the Principle of Mathematical Induction can be interpreted as follows: 1. The first domino falls over. 2. If one domino falls over, then the next domino will fall over. From this, we can conclude that any given domino will eventually fall over. That is, if we let P(n) be the predicate “The nth domino falls over,” then we can conclude ∀n ∈N, P(n) holds true.

However, for universal statements of the form For every integer n ≥M, P(n) is true, there is another technique known as the principle of mathematical induction that is often more effective. To introduce this principle, we first recall our working definition of N. This definition captures the essential structure of the natural numbers without going into the deeper foundations of set theory. Definition (Working Definition). The set of natural numbers N is the “smallest” set I such that 0 ∈I and (∀k ∈I, k + 1 ∈I). That is, let I be any set such that 0 ∈I and whenever k ∈I, then also k + 1 ∈I. The Peano axioms characterize N through logical rules, while in set theory (ZFC) one can construct N explicitly from the axioms.  Exercise 23.1.8. Show that the following sets are countably infinite. (a) A = {f : {0, 1} →N | f is a function} (b) B = the set of circles in R2 whose centers have integer coordinates and whose radii have rational lengths. (c) C = {f : N →N | ∀x ∈N, f(x + 1) = f(x) + 1} (d) D = the set of all “words”, where a “word” is a finite string of letters from the English alphabet. 23.2. Uncountable Sets So far, we have shown that many different infinite sets share the same size as N. This might naturally lead to the question: do uncountably infinite sets even exist? In this section, we will not only demonstrate that uncountably infinite sets do exist, but also establish that there are multiple distinct sizes (cardinalities) among uncountably infinite sets. Our main proof technique will be a powerful method known as diagonalization. 23.2.1. Uncountability of the Real Numbers To show that the real numbers are uncountable, we need to establish that there is no possible way to enumerate them. How can we prove that such an enumeration cannot exist? As is often done in mathematics, we will proceed by contradiction. To make this argument concrete, we will describe real numbers using their decimal expansions and apply a diagonalization argument. A real number x ∈R can be represented in its decimal form as x = x0.x1x2x3 · · · , where x0 ∈Z is the integer part, and xi ∈N with 0 ≤xi ≤9 for i ∈Z+ represent the decimal digits. For example, 5 6 = 0.83333 · · · = 0.83. Technical Note: Decimal representations are not always unique. In particular, a decimal that ends with an infinite sequence of 9’s is equal to the corresponding decimal that ends with an infinite sequence of 0’s. (This is usually proved in Calculus 2 using geometric series.) For example, 0.499999 · · · = 0.50000 · · · . To avoid this ambiguity, we adopt the following convention: a decimal representation of x ∈R is said to be in normalized form if it does not end with an infinite string of 9’s. 151

Let M be the smallest positive integer such that aM ̸= bM and assume that aM > bM. Prove that: • ai = bi for all 1 ≤i < M, • aM = bM + 1, • ai = 0 and bi = 9 for all i > M. With this convention in place, we can now use diagonalization to prove that there are uncountably many real numbers in the interval (0, 1). 152

The proof above illustrates the general idea behind diagonalization: given any attempt to list all elements of a certain set (for example, f(1), f(2), f(3), . . . ), we construct a new element that systematically differs from each listed one in at least one place. More precisely, the diagonalization strategy involves the following pattern: 1. Assume, for contradiction, that an enumeration of the set exists. 153

 2. Represent each element in a way that exposes infinitely many “coordinates” or distinguishable components (for example, digits of a real number, or values of a sequence). 3. Construct a new element by changing the nth coordinate (or component) of the nth listed element in a deliberate way. 4. Conclude that this new element differs from every element in the list, contradicting the assumption of a complete enumeration. The key feature of diagonalization is that the new element disagrees with the nth listed element in the nth component, ensuring that it is distinct from every item in the list. This strategy generalizes beyond decimal expansions. In each case, the heart of the argument is the same: no enumeration can capture every possible object once we can systematically construct one that escapes the list. Corollary 24.1.2. R is uncountable, and |R|= |(0, 1)|.

Conclude that this new element differs from every element in the list, contradicting the assumption of a complete enumeration. The key feature of diagonalization is that the new element disagrees with the nth listed element in the nth component, ensuring that it is distinct from every item in the list. This strategy generalizes beyond decimal expansions. In each case, the heart of the argument is the same: no enumeration can capture every possible object once we can systematically construct one that escapes the list. Corollary 24.1.2. Consider the following 2-step process for constructing a 2-card hand: • Select the first card from the deck: 52 choices. • Select the second card from the remaining 51 cards: 51 choices. 19 (Friends and Strangers Theorem). Suppose a party has six people. Consider any two of them: they are either meeting for the first time (mutual strangers) or already know each other (mutual acquaintances). The theorem states: “In any party of six people, at least three of them are (pairwise) mutual strangers or mutual acquaintances.” Proof. Label the six people as {a, b, c, d, e, f}. 1 (The Handshake Lemma). Suppose there are n people at a party, and everyone shakes hands with everyone else exactly once. How many handshakes occur in total? • Method 1: Each of the n people shakes hands with n −1 others. Counting all handshakes in this way gives n(n −1), but each handshake is counted twice (once for each participant). Thus, we divide by 2 to obtain the total number of unique handshakes: n(n −1) 2 . • Method 2: Number the n people from 1 to n. To avoid double counting, consider only the handshakes each person makes with those numbered lower than themselves. Let Ai denote the set of handshakes made by person i with people numbered below i. Since person i has i −1 such handshakes, we find |A|= n X i=1 |Ai|= n X i=1 (i −1) = n−1 X j=1 j. Since both expressions describe the total number of handshakes, they must be equal. Therefore, n(n −1) 2 = n−1 X j=1 j. This equality coincides with the formula for the sum of the first n −1 positive integers, which we previously proved by induction. The argument above illustrates a counting in two ways proof. We will encounter additional examples of this technique throughout the remainder of these notes. 209

For n ∈Z+, recall that {0, 1}n denotes the set of binary n-tuples. Let n ≥3. How many binary n-tuples are there that contain at least three 1’s? In many counting problems, it is easier to determine the size of the complement of a set rather than counting the set directly. Here, instead of counting all binary n-tuples with exactly three 1’s, four 1’s, . . . , up to n 1’s, it is simpler to count the number with zero, one, or two 1’s and subtract this from the total number of binary n-tuples. Define S = {0, 1}n. First, note that |S|= 2n since each component has two choices, 0 or 1. We now calculate the number of binary n-tuples with fewer than three 1’s. For each i ∈{0, 1, 2}, let Ai denote the subset of binary n-tuples that contain exactly i many 1’s. • |A0|= �n 0  = 1, because a binary n-tuple with no 1’s must be the tuple (0, 0, . . . , 0). • |A1|= �n 1  = n. Here we choose which one of the n components is 1; all remaining components are 0. • |A2|= �n 2  = n(n−1) 2 . We select two of the n components to be 1’s; all remaining components are 0. Since the sets A0, A1, A2 are pairwise disjoint, the Rule of Difference gives |S \ (A0 ∪A1 ∪A2)|= 2n − n 0  − n 1  − n 2  Thus, there are 2n − �n 0  − �n 1  − �n 2  binary n-tuples with at least three 1’s. Later, when we introduce the Principle of Inclusion–Exclusion, we will see how to handle complements when the relevant sets are not disjoint. This example motivates the following proposition. Proposition 34.1.5. For all n ∈N, 2n = nP i=0 �n i  . Below we present another example of a counting in two ways argument, using the Principle of Double Counting. 218

 Proof. Let n ∈N, and consider the set S = {0, 1}n of binary n-tuples. If n = 0, the only element of S is the empty string, so |S|= 20 = 1. For n ≥1, |S|= 2n by the arrangements-with-repetition formula, since each of the n components has two choices. Alternatively, we can count |S| by partitioning S as {Si | 0 ≤i ≤n}, where Si is the set of binary n-tuples with exactly i components equal to 1. Observe that if i ̸= j, then Si ∩Sj = ∅, because no binary n-tuple can have both i and j components equal to 1. Furthermore, n[ i=0 Si = S, since every binary n-tuple has between 0 and n entries equal to 1. Thus, {Si | 0 ≤i ≤n} is a partition of S. For each i ∈{0, 1, . . . , n}, we have |Si|= �n i  , since forming such a tuple amounts to choosing which i of the n components are 1’s. Using the Rule of Sum, |S|= n X i=0 |Si|= n X i=0 n i  . There are �n k  ways to do this. ▶From the k committee members, select one person to serve as chair. There are k choices. There are n choices. ▶From the remaining n−1 people, select k −1 additional committee members. There are �n−1 k−1  ways to do this. Again by the Rule of Product, |S|= n �n−1 k−1  . Since both procedures count the same set S, the two expressions for |S| must be equal. Therefore, k n k  = n n −1 k −1  . Remark.
