 Part III. Functions and Relations 88

 14. September 26 14.1. Binary Relations In this section, we will explore the concept of a binary relation between two sets (often just called a relation). The idea of a relation between two sets is already familiar to you. A binary relation allows us to compare or link elements from two sets. For instance, when we say 2 < 3, we are comparing two elements from Z. Similarly, when we say “Bill takes a class with Professor Johnson,” we are linking an element from the set of students with an element from the set of professors. We formalize this idea by defining a binary relation as a subset of the Cartesian product of the two sets being linked. Definition. Let S and T be sets. • If R ⊆S ×T, then R is called a binary relation between S and T. If (a, b) ∈R, we say that “a is in relation to b,” sometimes denoted aRb. • S is called the domain of R, and T is called the codomain of R. Many of the common relations in mathematics (and in other contexts) are relations where both elements belong to the same set (i.e., S = T). In that case, we simply say that R is a relation on S, meaning that R ⊆S × S. We begin by examining examples of binary relations, some linking elements of different sets, and others connecting elements of the same set. Examples 14.1.1. 1. Let S be the set of students at CMU and T be the set of professors at CMU. We define a relation R ⊆S × T such that (s, t) ∈R if and only if s has taken a class with t. That is, R = {(s, t) ∈S × T | s has taken a class with t}. For any given pair (s, t) of student and professor, we can determine whether s has taken a class with t by checking if (s, t) ∈R. 89

 2. The standard ordering relation < is a relation on sets such as R, Q, Z, and N. We can express this comparison as a set of ordered pairs. For instance, for x, y ∈R, we have x < y iff (x, y) ∈{(a, b) ∈R2 | ∃c ∈R+, (a + c = b)}. 3. The divisibility relation on the integers is another common example. Recall that for m, n ∈Z, we say that m | n if and only if there exists k ∈Z such that m·k = n. This relation can be viewed as the set of ordered pairs Rd: Rd = {(m, n) ∈Z2 | ∃k ∈Z, (m · k = n)}. 4. The subset relation ⊆is another familiar example. Let S be a set. We define the binary relation of ⊆on P(S) (the power set of S) such that for any A, B ∈P(S), the following holds: A ⊆B iff ∀x ∈S, (x ∈A →x ∈B). We can also express this relation as the set of ordered pairs, Rs: Rs = {(A, B) ∈P(S) × P(S) | ∀x ∈S, (x ∈A →x ∈B)}. 5. Functions are another important type of binary relation. Recall that for any relation R ⊆A × B, we say that A is the domain of R and B is the codomain of R. This terminology is most commonly used when f is a function. If f : A →B is a function, then A is the domain of f and B is the codomain of f. Examples 14.2.1. 1. Let S be any set. We define the identity function on S, denoted IdS or simply Id if the domain is clear from context, by IdS : S →S such that for all x ∈S, IdS(x) = x. That is, the identity function maps each element to itself. Equivalently, we can write IdS as the set of ordered pairs: IdS = {(x, x) | x ∈S}. 2. A mapping f : A →B is a well-defined function iff f satisfies the following conditions: 1. (Totality) For all a ∈A, f(a) is defined. (That is, A is the domain of f.) 2. Jections We now introduce a few special (and important!) types of functions: surjections, injections, and bijections. Injections Definition. Let A and B be sets, and let f : A →B be a function. We say that f is injective (or one-to-one) if and only if for all x, y ∈A, if f(x) = f(y), then x = y. 96

 Standard Injectivity Proof Outline • Let x, y ∈A such that f(x) = f(y). • Use the definition of f and other assumptions to show that x = y. • Conclude that f is injective. Then: 5x + 6 = 5y + 6. Subtracting 6 from both sides, we get 5x = 5y. Dividing both sides by 5 gives: x = y. Therefore, f is injective. In early algebra courses, we often say that a function f : R →R is injective if and only if it “passes the horizontal line test.” This means that any horizontal line drawn in the Cartesian plane will intersect the graph of the function at most once. In the case of the function f(x) = 5x + 6, the graph passes the horizontal line test, as shown on the right. We will consider three cases: (1) both x and y are positive, (2) both x and y are nonpositive, and (3) one is positive and the other is non-positive. • Case 1: Suppose x, y > 0. In this case, f(x) = f(y) implies 2x −1 = 2y −1. By adding 1 to both sides, we get 2x = 2y, and dividing by 2, we obtain x = y. • Case 2: Suppose x, y ≤0. Here, f(x) = f(y) implies −2x = −2y. Dividing both sides by −2, we get x = y. • Case 3: Without loss of generality, assume x > 0 and y ≤0. Then, f(x) = f(y) implies 2x −1 = −2y. Rearranging this, we have 2x + 2y = 1, or equivalently, x + y = 1 2. However, x + y ∈Z, while 1 2 /∈Z, a contradiction. Hence, this case is not possible. Since in all cases we either have x = y or a contradiction, we conclude that f(x) = f(y) implies x = y for all x, y ∈Z. Therefore, f is injective. Remark. (This is often done by explicitly constructing such an a.) • Conclude that f is surjective. Notice that surjectivity focuses on whether every element of the codomain is “hit” by the function. As a first illustration, let’s revisit the function from Example 16.1.2. Although it failed to be injective, we will see that it is surjective. Example 16.1.4. Define f : Z2 →Z by f(m, n) = m + n. Claim: f is a surjection. Proof. Let y ∈Z be arbitrary. We want to show that there exists (m, n) ∈Z2 such that f(m, n) = y. Consider (y, 0) ∈Z2. Then f(y, 0) = y + 0 = y. Since y was arbitrary, this proves that f is surjective. Example 16.1.5. Let f : Q →Q be defined by f(x) = 1 + 2x. Claim: f is a surjection. Proof. Let y ∈Q. Then y = m n for some m, n ∈Z with n ̸= 0. Fix such m and n. To find x such that f(x) = y, we need to solve 1 + 2x = m n . Rearranging the equation, we get x = m −n 2n . Since m and n are integers with n ̸= 0, it follows that x = m −n 2n ∈Q. Then f m −n 2n  = 1 + 2 · m −n 2n = 1 + m −n n = n + (m −n) n = m n = y. Since y ∈Q was arbitrary, we conclude that f is surjective. Next, let us revisit the function from Example 16.1.1. Earlier we showed it was injective; here we will prove that it is also surjective. This means the function actually turns out to be a bijection, though we will make that terminology precise later. 100

 Example 16.1.6. Define a function f : Z →N by f(n) = ( 2n −1 if n > 0, −2n if n ≤0. Claim: f is a surjection. Proof. Let y ∈N be arbitrary. We consider two cases: when y is even and when y is odd. • Case 1: Suppose y is even. Then y = 2k for some k ∈N. Consider x = −k. Since −k ≤0, we have f(x) = f(−k) = −2(−k) = 2k = y. • Case 2: Suppose y is odd. Then y = 2k+1 for some k ∈N. Consider x = k+1 ∈Z. Since k + 1 > 0, we have f(x) = f(k + 1) = 2(k + 1) −1 = 2k + 1 = y. Since we have addressed both possibilities, we conclude that f is surjective. Disproving Surjectivity A function f : A →B is not surjective if and only if there exists an element b ∈B such that f(a) ̸= b for all a ∈A. In other words, to disprove surjectivity it suffices to find a single element in the codomain that is not in the image of f. Example 16.1.7. Let f : R →R be defined by f(x) = x+|x| 2 . Claim: f is not a surjection. Proof. Consider y = −1 ∈R. Assume for the sake of contradiction that there exists x ∈R such that f(x) = −1. Then: x + |x| 2 = −1. We consider two cases based on the value of x: • Case 1: Suppose x ≥0. Then |x|= x, and the equation becomes x + x 2 = −1 =⇒2x 2 = −1 =⇒x = −1. But this contradicts our assumption that x ≥0. 101

 • Case 2: Suppose x < 0. Then |x|= −x, and the equation becomes x −x 2 = −1 =⇒0 2 = −1 =⇒0 = −1, which is a contradiction. Since both cases lead to a contradiction, there is no x ∈R such that f(x) = −1. Thus, −1 is not in the image of f, and f is not surjective.

We have already encountered some examples of bijections, though we did not explicitly call them that at the time. Example 16.1.9. Define f : Z →N by f(n) = ( 2n −1 if n > 0, −2n if n ≤0. Recall from Example 16.1.1 that we proved f is injective, and from Example 16.1.6 that f is surjective. Therefore, f is a bijection. 102

Then f y −6 5  = 5 y −6 5  + 6 = y. Therefore, f maps onto all of R, proving that f is surjective. Since f is both injective and surjective, it follows that f is a bijection. We now formalize it into a general strategy. Proving Bijectivity – Method 1 To prove that a function f : X →Y is a bijection, you need to: • Prove that f is an injection (i.e., for all x1, x2 ∈X, if f(x1) = f(x2) then x1 = x2). • Prove that f is a surjection (i.e., for every y ∈Y , there exists x ∈X such that f(x) = y). We will prove that f is both injective and surjective. • Injectivity: Let x1, x2 ∈R such that f(x1) = f(x2). We consider three cases: Case 1: Assume x1, x2 < 1. Then 1 x1 −1 = 1 x2 −1. Rearranging gives x1 −1 = x2 −1, so x1 = x2, as required. Case 2: Assume x1, x2 ≥1. Then √ x1 −1 = √ x2 −1. Squaring both sides yields x1 −1 = x2 −1, so x1 = x2. 103

 Case 3: Without loss of generality, assume x1 < 1 and x2 ≥1. Then f(x1) = 1 x1 −1 < 0, f(x2) = √ x2 −1 ≥0. Since a negative number cannot equal a nonnegative number, this contradicts the assumption that f(x1) = f(x2). Since all cases either forced x1 = x2 or led to a contradiction, we conclude that f is injective. • Surjectivity: Let y ∈R. We want to show there exists x ∈R such that f(x) = y. We split into two cases: Case 1: Suppose y < 0. Define x = 1 y + 1. Since y ̸= 0 and y < 0, it follows that x < 1. Then f(x) = f 1 y + 1  = 1 1 y + 1 −1 = 1 1 y = y. Case 2: Suppose y ≥0. Define x = y2 + 1. Since y2 ≥0, we have x ≥1. Then f(x) = f(y2 + 1) = p y2 + 1 −1 = p y2 = |y|= y, where the last equality holds because y ≥0. In both cases, we have found an x ∈R such that f(x) = y. Therefore, f is surjective. Since f is both injective and surjective, we conclude that f is a bijection. Composition and Inverses of Functions Before introducing a second method for proving bijectivity, we first need to define the operation of composing functions. Definition. Let A, B, and C be sets, and let f : A →B and g : B →C be functions. The composition of g and f is the function h : A →C defined by h(a) = g(f(a)) for all a ∈A. We denote this by h = g ◦f. Let A, B, C, and D be sets, and let f : A →B, g : B →C, and h : C →D be functions. Then h ◦(g ◦f) = (h ◦g) ◦f. Proof. Let a ∈A. Composition and Inverses of Functions The following theorem summarizes key properties of function composition with respect to injections, surjections, and bijections. Theorem 17.1.1. Let A, B, and C be sets, and let f : A →B and g : B →C be functions. Then the following properties hold: 1 If f and g are injections, then g ◦f : A →C is also an injection. 2 If f and g are surjections, then g ◦f : A →C is also a surjection. 3 If f and g are bijections, then g ◦f : A →C is also a bijection. Proof. 1 Assume that f : A →B and g : B →C are injections. We will show that g ◦f : A →C is injective. Let a1, a2 ∈A such that (g ◦f)(a1) = (g ◦f)(a2). By the definition of composition, this gives: g(f(a1)) = g(f(a2)). Since g is injective, we conclude: f(a1) = f(a2). And since f is injective, it follows that a1 = a2. Therefore, g ◦f is injective. 2 The proof that g ◦f is surjective is left as an exercise for recitation. 3 Since g ◦f is both injective (by 1 ) and surjective (by 2 ), it is bijective. 106

 Inverses Now that we have defined function composition, we can introduce the concept of inverse functions and prove an important result about bijections. Definition. Let A and B be sets, and let f : A →B and g : B →A be functions. • g is called a left inverse of f if and only if g ◦f = IdA. • g is called a right inverse of f if and only if f ◦g = IdB. • g is called a (two-sided) inverse of f if and only if g is both a left and a right inverse. • f is invertible if and only if f has a two-sided inverse. Notation: If f is invertible, we denote its inverse function by f−1. While not every function is invertible, an important property of inverses is that if they exist, they are unique. Theorem 17.1.2 (Uniqueness of Inverses). Let A and B be sets, and let f : A →B be a function. If f is invertible, then its inverse function f−1 is unique. Proof. Let f : A →B be invertible. Suppose g : B →A and g′ : B →A are both inverses of f. We want to show that g = g′. Since g and g′ are inverses of f, we know: f ◦g = IdB, g ◦f = IdA, f ◦g′ = IdB, g′ ◦f = IdA. Let b ∈B be arbitrary. Then g(b) = (g ◦IdB)(b) = (g ◦(f ◦g′))(b) = ((g ◦f) ◦g′)(b) = (IdA ◦g′)(b) = g′(b). Thus, g(b) = g′(b) for all b ∈B, which shows g = g′. Therefore, the inverse of f is unique. We now establish our major result for this section. Theorem 17.1.3. Let A and B be sets, and let f : A →B be a function. Then f is invertible if and only if f is a bijection. Proof. 107

 (⇒): Suppose f is invertible. Then there exists a function g : B →A such that g ◦f = IdA and f ◦g = IdB. We show that f is a bijection. ▶Injective: Let a1, a2 ∈A with f(a1) = f(a2). Applying g to both sides gives g(f(a1)) = g(f(a2)). Since g ◦f = IdA, it follows that idA(a1) = IdA(a2) =⇒ a1 = a2. Hence f is injective. ▶Surjective: Let b ∈B be arbitrary. Define a = g(b) ∈A. Since f and g are inverses, we have f(a) = f(g(b)) = IdB(b) = b. Hence f is surjective. Thus f is both injective and surjective, so f is a bijection. (⇐): Suppose f is a bijection (i.e., injective and surjective). Define the relation g = {(b, a) ∈B × A | f(a) = b}. We show g is a function from B to A. Let b ∈B. Since f is surjective, there exists a ∈A such that f(a) = b, so (b, a) ∈g. To show uniqueness, suppose (b, a), (b, a′) ∈g. Then f(a) = b = f(a′). Since f is injective, a = a′. Thus each b ∈B corresponds to a unique a ∈A, so g is a function. By construction, f ◦g = IdB and g ◦f = IdA. Hence g is the inverse of f, so f is invertible. From this theorem, we obtain a second method for proving bijectivity. Proving Bijectivity – Method 2 To prove that f : A →B is a bijection, it suffices to show that f is invertible. • Construct the inverse function g : B →A and prove that it is well-defined. • Prove that f ◦g = IdB. • Prove that g ◦f = IdA. • Conclude that g = f−1 and hence f is a bijection. 108

 Note. This method is best suited to functions defined by simple rules (where one can easily solve for x in terms of f(x)). For more complicated functions (especially piecewise ones), it is typically clearer to prove injectivity and surjectivity directly. Example 17.1.4. Let S = R ∖{3} and T = R ∖{1}. Define f : S →T by f(x) = x −2 x −3. Prove that f is a bijection. Scratch work: y = x −2 x −3 =⇒xy −3y = x −2 =⇒x(y −1) = 3y −2 =⇒x = 3y −2 y −1 . Proof. Define g : T →S by g(x) = 3x −2 x −1 . We will show that g is the inverse of f. • Well-Definedness: Since x ̸= 1 for all x ∈T, the expression 3x −2 x −1 is defined. If x1 = x2, then clearly 3x1 −2 x1 −1 = 3x2 −2 x2 −1 , so g(x1) = g(x2). To check that g(x) ∈S, we verify that g(x) ̸= 3 for all x ∈T: g(x) = 3 ⇐⇒ 3x −2 x −1 = 3 ⇐⇒ 3x −2 = 3x −3 ⇐⇒ −2 = −3, a contradiction. Hence g(x) ∈S for all x ∈T, and g is well-defined. • Computation of g ◦f: Let x ∈S. Then (g ◦f)(x) = g(f(x)) = g x −2 x −3  = 3  x−2 x−3  −2  x−2 x−3  −1 = 3(x −2) −2(x −3) (x −2) −(x −3) = x 1 = x. Therefore g ◦f = IdS. 109

 • Computation of f ◦g: Let x ∈T. Then (f ◦g)(x) = f(g(x)) = f 3x −2 x −1  =  3x−2 x−1  −2  3x−2 x−1  −3 = (3x −2) −2(x −1) (3x −2) −3(x −1) = x 1 = x. Therefore f ◦g = IdT . Since g = f−1, we conclude that f is invertible, and hence f is a bijection.

 18. October 6 18.1. Homogeneous Relations Now that we’ve explored functions as a special type of binary relation, we turn our attention to relations where the domain and codomain are the same set. These are called homogeneous relations. Such relations are especially important because many of the most familiar mathematical structures, such as orderings and equivalence relations, are defined in terms of simple properties like reflexivity, symmetry, and transitivity. By studying these properties in isolation, we will see how they combine to give rise to these richer and more structured types of relations. Definition. Let R be a binary relation on a set S. Then R is called: • Reflexive iff ∀x ∈S, (x, x) ∈R (i.e., every element is related to itself). • Irreflexive iff ∀x ∈S, (x, x) /∈R (i.e., no element is related to itself). • Symmetric iff ∀x, y ∈S, ((x, y) ∈R →(y, x) ∈R). • Antisymmetric iff ∀x, y ∈S, (((x, y) ∈R ∧(y, x) ∈R) →x = y). • Transitive iff ∀x, y, z ∈S, (((x, y) ∈R ∧(y, z) ∈R) →(x, z) ∈R). • Total iff ∀x, y ∈S, (x ̸= y →((x, y) ∈R ∨(y, x) ∈R)) (i.e., any two distinct elements are comparable). Notes. • Irreflexivity vs. Reflexivity: Irreflexivity is not the opposite of reflexivity. Both are universal statements. The only time a relation can be both reflexive and irreflexive is when the set S is empty. However, many relations are neither reflexive nor irreflexive. • Symmetry vs. Antisymmetry: Antisymmetry is not the opposite of symmetry. These properties are not logical negations of one another. The only relations that are both symmetric and antisymmetric are subsets of the equality relation. However, many relations are neither symmetric nor antisymmetric. • Contrapositive in Antisymmetry: In some cases, the hypothesis of antisymmetry (both (x, y) and (y, x) being in R) may never hold. In such cases, it is useful 111

 to consider the contrapositive: if x ̸= y, then either (x, y) /∈R or (y, x) /∈R. Below we examine several common binary relations and determine whether they satisfy these properties. Let S = [5] and define R ⊆S2 as follows: R = {(1, 1), (1, 2), (1, 3), (2, 2), (2, 3), (3, 3), (4, 4), (5, 5)} Determine whether or not R satisfies the following properties. Provide brief justifications. (a) Reflexivity (b) Irreflexivity (c) Symmetry (d) Antisymmetry (e) Transitivity (f) Totality At this point, we turn our attention to two special types of relations on sets—equivalence relations and order relations. 18.1.1. Equivalence Relations In previous math courses, you may have encountered situations where objects that are distinct in one context are considered equivalent in another. For example, angles such as 0◦, 360◦, and 720◦differ numerically, but they represent the same direction when drawn on a circle. Similarly, in geometry, two similar triangles are often treated as equivalent because they share the same angles, even if their side lengths differ. These examples highlight how, depending on the context, certain differences are ignored and objects are regarded as “essentially the same.” 112

 Definition. A relation R on a set S is called an equivalence relation if and only if R is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. Equivalence relations arise in many mathematical contexts. Here are some common examples: 1. Equality on any set. 2. Similarity of triangles: △A ∼△B if and only if they have the same interior angles. 3. Rounding real numbers to the nearest integer: two real numbers x and y are equivalent if they round to the same nearest integer. x ∼y ⇐⇒∃n ∈Z such that x, y ∈  n −1 2, n + 1 2  . 4. Logical equivalence in propositional logic. 5. Parity on Z: two integers a and b are equivalent if and only if they have the same parity (i.e., both are even or both are odd). One of the most commonly used equivalence relations in mathematics and computer science is congruence modulo m on the integers. We now give the formal definition of this relation. Definition. Let m ∈Z+. For any a, b ∈Z, we say that a is congruent to b modulo m, denoted a ≡b (mod m), if and only if m | (a −b). Theorem 18.1.3. For any m ∈Z+, congruence modulo m is an equivalence relation on Z. Proof. Let m ∈Z+. We will show that congruence modulo m is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. • (Reflexivity): Let a ∈Z. We want to show that a ≡a (mod m). Since a −a = 0 = m · 0, we have m | (a −a), and thus a ≡a (mod m), as desired. • (Symmetry): Let a, b ∈Z with a ≡b (mod m). We want to show that b ≡a (mod m). Since a ≡b (mod m), we have m | (a −b), meaning a −b = mk for some k ∈Z. It follows that b −a = m(−k), which implies m | (b −a) because −k ∈Z. Therefore, b ≡a (mod m), as desired. 113

 • (Transitivity): Let a, b, c ∈Z such that a ≡b (mod m) and b ≡c (mod m). We want to show that a ≡c (mod m). From a ≡b (mod m), we have a −b = mk for some k ∈Z. From b ≡c (mod m), we have b −c = mℓfor some ℓ∈Z. Summing these equations gives: a −c = (a −b) + (b −c) = mk + mℓ= m(k + ℓ) Thus m | (a −c), and therefore a ≡c (mod m). Since congruence modulo m is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive, it follows that it is an equivalence relation on Z. Congruence modulo m is often used to describe sets with cyclic structure. Even if you have not encountered the terminology before, you have almost certainly used the idea. Here are some familiar examples: • Days of the week: The days repeat every 7 days. For instance, if 25 days ago was a Monday, then today is a Friday because 25 ≡4 (mod 7), meaning it is 4 days past a Monday. • Clocks: Converting between 24-hour and 12-hour time uses congruence modulo 12. For example, 16 : 00 satisfies 16 ≡4 (mod 12), so the time is 4:00 PM in 12-hour notation. • Parity: Odd and even integers can be described using congruence modulo 2. We have a ≡b (mod 2) if and only if a −b is even, meaning a and b have the same parity. • Angles: Angles measured in degrees can be treated using congruence modulo 360. For example, 375 ≡15 (mod 360), so 375◦and 15◦are coterminal. To get a handle on this equivalence relation, let’s consider the case of m = 3. A few quick observations about which integers are or are not congruent to one another: • 26 ≡2 (mod 3) because 3 | (26 −2) • 0 ≡3 (mod 3) because 3 | (0 −3) • 7 ̸≡21 (mod 3) because 3 ∤(7 −21) 114

 19. October 8 19.1. Homogeneous Relations 19.1.1. Equivalence Classes The purpose of defining an equivalence relation is to identify the underlying structure of equality in order to generalize it to other contexts. Since an equivalence relation defines a new notion of two elements being the same, it is useful to discuss sets of elements that are all considered the same as each other. Below, we make precise this idea of being the same. Definition. Let R be an equivalence relation on a set S. For every x ∈S, we define the equivalence class of x under R, denoted [x]R, by [x]R = {y ∈S | (x, y) ∈R} That is, [x]R is the collection of all elements that are equivalent to x, under the specific notion of equivalence being discussed. The set of all equivalence classes is referred to as the quotient set, denoted S/R, read “S modulo R”. That is S/R = {[x]R | x ∈S} Because congruence modulo m is a commonly used equivalence relation, the set of equivalence classes (commonly called congruence classes in this context) has a special notation. Special Notation For m ∈Z+, the set S/R of congruence classes modulo m is denoted by Z/mZ. This set contains m equivalence classes: Z/mZ = {[0]m, [1]m, [2]m, . . . , [m −1]m}. We often write integers as if they were their equivalence classes, viewing Z/mZ as a cycle of m distinct classes. 115

 Example 19.1.1. Consider congruence modulo 3 on Z. What do the equivalence classes look like? [0]3 = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x −0)} = {x ∈Z | ∃k ∈Z, (x = 3k)} = {. . . , −3, 0, 3, 6, 9, 12, . . .} [1]3 = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x −1)} = {x ∈Z | ∃k ∈Z, (x = 3k + 1)} = {. . . , −5, −2, 1, 4, 7, . . .} [2]3 = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x −2)} = {x ∈Z | ∃k ∈Z, (x = 3k + 2)} = {. . . , −4, −1, 2, 5, 8, . . .} [3]3 = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x −3)} = {x ∈Z | 3 | x} = [0]3 [4]3 = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x −4)} = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x −1)} = [1]3 [5]3 = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x −5)} = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x −2)} = [2]3 We should also look at some equivalence classes for negative integers: [−1]3 = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x + 1)} = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x −2)} = [2]3 [−2]3 = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x + 2)} = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x −1)} = [1]3 [−3]3 = {x ∈Z | 3 | (x + 3)} = {x ∈Z | 3 | x} = [0]3 Let’s make a few observations about these equivalence classes and how they relate to our original set, Z. • There are 3 distinct equivalence classes: [0]3, [1]3, and [2]3. • Each equivalence class is an infinite set of integers. • The union of the equivalence classes gives the entire set: [0]3 ∪[1]3 ∪[2]3 = Z. • The equivalence classes are pairwise disjoint. • We have S/R = Z/3Z = {[0]3, [1]3, [2]3}. [0]3 [1]3 [2]3 Figure 19.1.: The equivalence classes of Z/3Z arranged in a cycle.

For each of the following, prove that the given relation is an equivalence relation and describe the different equivalence classes. (a) Suppose f : A →B is a function. Define the relation ∼on B by x ∼y ⇐⇒ PreImf({x}) = PreImf({y}) 116

 (b) Define ≃on Z by x ≃y ⇐⇒ |x|= |y| (c) Define ∼= on Z by x ∼= y ⇐⇒ 11 | 4x + 7y (d) Define .= on Q ∖{0} by x .= y ⇐⇒ ∃k ∈Z, x y = 2k (e) Define ≈on Z by x ≈y ⇐⇒ cos(x) cos(y) > 0 19.1.2. The Fundamental Theorem of Equivalence Relations In the previous example of Z/3Z, the congruence classes modulo 3 formed what we call a partition of Z. Definition. Let S be a set, I be an index set, and Ai ⊆S for each i ∈I. Then {Ai | i ∈I} is called a partition of S if and only if: 1. For each i ∈I, Ai ̸= ∅. 2. For each i, j ∈I, either Ai = Aj or Ai ∩Aj = ∅. 3. S i∈I Ai = S. That is, {Ai | i ∈I} is a partition of S if and only if the Ai’s divide S into nonempty, non-overlapping pieces. Figure 19.2.: An illustration of a partition of a set. Returning to Example 19.1.1, we see that Z/3Z = {[0]3, [1]3, [2]3} satisfies the three properties of a partition: 1. Each congruence class in Z/3Z is a nonempty subset of the integers. 117

 2. Any two congruence classes in Z/3Z are either equal to each other or disjoint from each other. 3. The union of the three distinct congruence classes in Z/3Z is all of Z. It is not a coincidence that Z/3Z is a partition of Z. In fact, this phenomenon holds for all equivalence relations (and conversely), as the following theorem states. Theorem 19.1.3 (Fundamental Theorem of Equivalence Relations). Let S be a nonempty set. Then the following hold: 1. If R is an equivalence relation on S, then S/R is a partition of S. 2. If F is a partition of S, then there exists an equivalence relation R on S such that S/R = F. Before proving this theorem (or at least one direction of it—we’ll leave the other for homework), let’s look at a concrete example of the reverse direction. We’ve already seen how an equivalence relation produces a partition; now we’ll see how a partition gives rise to an equivalence relation. Example 19.1.4. Let S = [6] and F = {{1}, {2, 5, 6}, {3, 4}} be a partition of S. We want to find an equivalence relation R on S such that S/R = F. Define R ⊆S × S by declaring two elements related if they belong to the same block of the partition. Explicitly, R = {(1, 1), (2, 2), (2, 5), (2, 6), (3, 3), (3, 4), (4, 3), (4, 4), (5, 2), (5, 5), (5, 6), (6, 2), (6, 5), (6, 6)}. We can manually check that R is an equivalence relation on S. • (R): Is (x, x) ∈R for each x ∈[6]? ✓ • (S): For each (x, y) ∈R, is (y, x) ∈R also? ✓ • (T): For each (x, y), (y, z) ∈R, is (x, z) ∈R also? ✓ So, R is an equivalence relation on S, and S/R has 3 distinct equivalence classes. [1]R = {1}, [2]R = [5]R = [6]R = {2, 5, 6}, [3]R = [4]R = {3, 4}. Thus, the set of equivalence classes is exactly the given partition: S/R = {[1]R, [2]R, [3]R} = F. We now proceed to prove the theorem. 118

 Proof. 1. Homework 2. Let F = {Si}i∈I be a partition of S. Define a relation R on S by R = {(x, y) ∈S | ∃i ∈I, (x ∈Si ∧y ∈Si)}. We want to show that R is an equivalence relation and that S/R = F. First, we check reflexivity, symmetry, and transitivity. • (R): Let x ∈S. Since F is a partition of S, we have S i∈I Si = S. Hence, x ∈Si for some i ∈I, by the definition of an indexed union. Fix such an i. Then x ∈Si implies that (x, x) ∈R, as desired. • (S): Let x, y ∈S such that (x, y) ∈R. Then, by definition of R, we have x ∈ Si ∧y ∈Si for some i ∈I. Fix such an i. Since conjunction is commutative, this implies y ∈Si ∧x ∈Si. Hence (y, x) ∈R, as desired. • (T): Let x, y, z ∈S such that (x, y), (y, z) ∈R. Then, by definition of R, there exists i ∈I such that x ∈Si ∧y ∈Si, and there exists j ∈I such that y ∈Sj ∧z ∈Sj. Fix such i and j. Since F is a partition of S and y ∈Si and y ∈Sj, it must be the case that Si = Sj (the pieces of a partition are either equal or disjoint). Thus, x ∈Si ∧z ∈Si, implying that (x, z) ∈R, as desired. Therefore, R is an equivalence relation on S. It remains to show S/R = F. We proceed by double containment. • (⊆): Let A ∈S/R. Then, by definition, A = [x]R for some x ∈S. Since F is a partition, x belongs to exactly one block Si ∈F. Then A = [x]R = {y ∈S | y ∈Si} = Si. Therefore, A ∈F, as desired. • (⊇): Let Si ∈F. Since F is a partition, Si ̸= ∅. Fix x ∈Si. By uniqueness of the partition blocks, Si is the only block of F containing x. Thus [x]R = {y ∈S | y ∈Si} = Si, so Si ∈S/R. By double containment, we conclude that S/R = F. The utility of equivalence relations extends beyond classification: they provide the foundation for many mathematical structures, such as quotient groups in group theory and partitions in topology. Recognizing and applying these concepts will deepen your understanding of advanced mathematics and the connections between its different areas. 119

 19.1.3. (Optional) Formal Constructions of Z and Q Previously, we discussed how to construct the natural numbers (or a structure having the same properties as N) from the axioms of set theory. Now, with the power of equivalence relations, we can formally construct the integers and rational numbers. This approach allows us to define addition and multiplication on these sets in a way that is consistent with the operations we already take for granted. Constructing the Integers The natural numbers do not include additive inverses, so subtraction is not always possible within N. To address this, we will construct the integers by introducing formal differences. The guiding idea is that an ordered pair (a, b) ∈N2 represents the “formal difference” a −b. However, we must be careful: since subtraction is not defined in N, we cannot simply say (a, b) = (c, d) whenever a −b = c −d. Instead, we use the following property of N: Cancellation Law: If k + m = n + m then k = n. This motivates the following definition. Theorem 19.1.5. Define a relation ∼on N2 by (a, b) ∼(c, d) ⇐⇒ a + d = b + c. Then ∼is an equivalence relation on N2. Proof. To be completed in recitation. The quotient set N2/∼will represent our set of integers. Each equivalence class [(a, b)]∼ under this relation represents the integer corresponding to the formal difference a −b. For example, [(3, 1)]∼ represents 3 −1 = 2, [(2, 5)]∼ represents 2 −5 = −3. We now want to define addition and multiplication on N2/∼in a way that matches how these operations behave in Z. For instance, we want 2 + (−3) to correspond to [(3, 1)]∼+ [(2, 5)]∼, and the result should represent −1. Similarly, 2 · (−3) should correspond to [(3, 1)]∼· [(2, 5)]∼, 120

 and the result should represent −6. Motivated by these examples, we define our operations as follows. Definition. We define addition on N2/∼by [(a, b)]∼+ [(c, d)]∼= [(a + c, b + d)]∼, and multiplication by [(a, b)]∼· [(c, d)]∼= [(ac + bd, ad + bc)]∼. Recall that equivalence classes can be represented by multiple ordered pairs. For example, [(2, 0)]∼= [(3, 1)]∼= [(4, 2)]∼= · · · Our definitions above used specific representatives, so we must verify that the operations are well-defined. That is, the result does not depend on the choice of representative. Theorem 19.1.6. The operations defined above are well-defined. In particular, if (a, b) ∼(a′, b′) and (c, d) ∼(c′, d′), then: 1. (a + c, b + d) ∼(a′ + c′, b′ + d′), 2. (ac + bd, ad + bc) ∼(a′c′ + b′d′, a′d′ + b′c′). Equivalently, if [(a, b)]∼= [(a′, b′)]∼and [(c, d)]∼= [(c′, d′)]∼, then [(a, b)]∼+[(c, d)]∼= [(a′, b′)]∼+[(c′, d′)]∼ and [(a, b)]∼·[(c, d)]∼= [(a′, b′)]∼·[(c′, d′)]∼. Before proving this theorem, let’s explore an example. Example 19.1.7. Suppose we want to represent the sum 2 + 3. Using our definition of addition, we could write: [(2, 0)]∼+ [(3, 0)]∼= [(2 + 3, 0 + 0)]∼= [(5, 0)]∼, which represents the number 5, as expected. But we could also represent 2 and 3 differently: [(3, 1)]∼+ [(10, 7)]∼= [(3 + 10, 1 + 7)]∼= [(13, 8)]∼, which also represents the number 5. Our theorem states that no matter which representatives of 2 and 3 we choose, the sum will always represent 5. Similarly, for the product 2 · 3 = 6: [(2, 0)]∼· [(3, 0)]∼= [(6 + 0, 0 + 0)]∼= [(6, 0)]∼ 121

 represents 6, while [(3, 1)]∼· [(10, 7)]∼= [(30 + 7, 21 + 10)]∼= [(37, 31)]∼ also represents 6. This illustrates that multiplication, too, should be independent of the choice of representatives. We now proceed to prove the theorem. Proof. Let (a, b), (a′, b′), (c, d), (c′, d′) ∈N2 such that (a, b) ∼(a′, b′) and (c, d) ∼(c′, d′). 1. We want to show that (a + c, b + d) ∼(a′ + c′, b′ + d′). By assumption, a + b′ = b + a′ and c + d′ = d + c′. Adding these two equalities gives a + c + b′ + d′ = b + d + a′ + c′, which shows (a + c, b + d) ∼(a′ + c′, b′ + d′). Thus, addition is well-defined on Z. 2. We want to show that (ac + bd, ad + bc) ∼(a′c′ + b′d′, a′d′ + b′c′). As in the previous case, from our assumptions we have a + b′ = b + a′ and c + d′ = d + c′. Multiplying the first equality by c and d, and the second by a′ and b′, we obtain c(a + b′) = c(b + a′), d(a + b′) = d(b + a′), and a′(c + d′) = a′(d + c′), b′(c + d′) = b′(d + c′). Expanding both sides gives ac+bd+a′d′ +b′c′ +b′c+a′d+a′c+b′d = ad+bc+a′c′ +b′d′ +a′c+b′d+a′d+b′c. Order relations generalize the familiar concepts of <, ≤, and ⊆. Definition. • A relation R on a set S is called a partial order if and only if R is reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive. • If R is a partial order on S, then (S, R) is called a partially ordered set (or poset). For example, (P(S), ⊆) (for any set S) and (R, ≤) are posets. • A relation R is called a strict partial order if and only if R is irreflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive. For example, (P(S), ⊊) and (R, <) are strict partial orders. • A relation R is called a total order (or linear order) if and only if it is a partial order in which every pair of elements of S is comparable under R. As mentioned above, (P(S), ⊆) and (R, ≤) are two of the most common partial orders. The definition of a partial order can thus be viewed as a generalization of these familiar examples. Let’s begin by proving that ⊆is a partial order on a power set. Example 20.1.1. Consider the relation ⊆on P(N). We will prove that ⊆is a partial order on P(N). Proof. We must show that ⊆is reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive. • (R): Let X ∈P(N). For every n ∈N, if n ∈X, then n ∈X, trivially. Thus X ⊆X. • (AS): Let X, Y ∈P(N) such that X ⊆Y and Y ⊆X. y the definition of set equality, this implies X = Y . 126

 • (T): Let X, Y, Z ∈P(N) such that X ⊆Y and Y ⊆Z. Let x ∈X. Since X ⊆Y , we have x ∈Y ; and since Y ⊆Z, we have x ∈Z. Therefore X ⊆Z. Hence, (P(N), ⊆) is a poset. A partial order in which all pairs of elements are comparable is called a total order (or linear order). A standard example of a total order is (R, ≤), and a standard example of a strict total order is (R, <). By contrast, ⊆serves as the canonical example of a partial order that is not total. Example 20.1.2. Consider the set N2. How can we linearly order the elements of this set? A natural first attempt might be to define (a, b) ≺(c, d) iff a < c and b < d. However, while this defines a strict partial order, it fails to satisfy totality. For instance, (1, 2) ̸≺(2, 1) and (2, 1) ̸≺(1, 2). Instead, we can order the elements of N2 in the same way we alphabetize words: by comparing the first components and, if they are equal, comparing the second components. This is known as the lexicographic ordering of N2. (a, b) ≺(c, d) iff (a < c) ∨((a = c) ∧(b < d)). Claim. The relation ≺is a strict total order on N2. Proof. We show that ≺is irreflexive, antisymmetric, transitive, and total. • (IR): Let (a, b) ∈N2. Since neither a < a nor b < b holds, we have (a, b) ̸≺(a, b). • (AS): We will prove the contrapositive of the definition of antisymmetry. Let (a, b), (c, d) ∈N2 such that (a, b) ̸= (c, d). We want to show (a, b) ̸≺(c, d) or (c, d) ̸≺(a, b). Since (a, b) ̸= (c, d), either a ̸= c or b ̸= d. We consider the cases of a = c and a ̸= c. ▶Case 1: a ̸= c. Without loss of generality, we may assume that a < c. Then (c, d) ̸≺(a, b) since c ̸< a. ▶Case 2: a = c. Since (a, b) ̸= (c, d) and a = c, it must be the case that b ̸= d. Without loss of generality, we may assume that b < d. Then (c, d) ̸≺(a, b) since c = a but d ̸< b. 127

From (a, b) ≺(c, d), we have a < c or (a = c ∧b < d); from (c, d) ≺(e, f), we have c < e or (c = e ∧d < f). Consider cases: ▶Case 1: a < e. Then (a, b) ≺(e, f) by definition. ▶Case 2: a = e. Then it must be the case that a = c = e. Since (a, b) ≺(c, d) and a = c, we have b < d. Similarly, since (c, d) ≺(e, f) and c = e, we have d < f. Therefore, since b < d and d < f, we have b < f. Thus, (a, b) ≺(e, f), as desired. Therefore ≺is transitive. • (TO): Let (a, b), (c, d) ∈N2 with (a, b) ̸= (c, d). Then either a ̸= c or b ̸= d. ▶If a ̸= c, then either a < c or c < a. In the first case (a, b) ≺(c, d), and in the second (c, d) ≺(a, b). ▶If a = c and b ̸= d, then either b < d or d < b. In the first case (a, b) ≺(c, d), and in the second (c, d) ≺(a, b). A relation R on a set U is called asymmetric if and only if for all x, y ∈U, if (x, y) ∈R then (y, x) /∈R. Prove that a relation R on a set U is asymmetric if and only if R is both anti-symmetric and irreflexive. 20.2. End Exam 2 Material 129

 Part IV. Cardinality 130

 21. October 20 21.1. Introduction Informally, the cardinality of a set S, denoted |S|, is the number of elements in the set. For finite sets, this definition is straightforward. However, for infinite sets, it is not immediately clear how we can define the notion of two infinite sets having the same cardinality. Below are some initial questions we might consider: 1 How should we compare the sizes of sets? 2 What does it mean for two sets to have the same size? 3 Should all infinite sets be considered the same size? To motivate our exploration of Questions 1 and 2 , let’s begin with a simpler case. Simpler Question: How can we determine whether two finite sets have the same size? One possible answer is to count the elements in each set. However, this approach breaks down when the sets are infinite. A more flexible method is to pair the elements of the two sets. If we can match each element of set A with exactly one element of set B, with no elements left unmatched in either set, then the two sets must contain the same number of elements. Example 21.1.1. Let A = {w, x, y, z} and B = {♡, ♢, ♣, ♠}. w ↔ ♡ x ↔ ♢ y ↔ ♣ z ↔ ♠ What we are actually doing here is defining a bijection f : A →B. This idea extends naturally to sets of any size and leads to our formal definition of “having the same cardinality.” 131

 Definition. Two sets A and B are said to have the same cardinality, or to be equinumerous, denoted |A|= |B|, if and only if there exists a bijection f : A →B. To better understand this definition, let’s look at some examples. Example 21.1.2. Let A = {a, b, c} and B = {d}. Since A has three elements while B has only one, it is clear that |A|̸= |B|. This can also be seen from the definition: any function f : A →B must map every element of A to d, which makes f non-injective. Therefore, no bijection can exist between A and B. Example 21.1.3. Let E be the set of even integers. The function f : Z →E defined by f(n) = 2n is a bijection. Hence, the set of even integers has the same cardinality as the set of all integers: |E|= |Z|. Example 21.1.4. Recall from Example 16.1.9 the function f : Z →N given by f(n) = ( 2n −1, if n > 0, −2n, if n ≤0. This function is a bijection, showing that |Z|= |N|. In other words, the integers and natural numbers have the same cardinality. Example 21.1.5. The function f : (0, 1) →(0, 2) defined by f(x) = 2x is a bijection. Thus, the number of real numbers in the interval (0, 1) is equal to the number in (0, 2); that is, |(0, 1)|= |(0, 2)|. Example 21.1.6. The function f : (0, 1) →R, defined by f(x) = ln � 1−x x  , provides a bijection from (0, 1) to the entire real line. Therefore, |(0, 1)|= |R|: there are just as many real numbers in (0, 1) as there are in all of R. With these examples in mind, we will next focus on finite sets. Our goal will be to show that this formal definition of cardinality agrees with our intuitive understanding of “counting” elements. 21.2. Finite Sets We begin by formally defining what it means for a set to be finite or infinite. 132

 Definitions. • A set X is said to be finite iff there exists some n ∈N and a bijection f : [n] →X. In this case, we define the cardinality of X to be |X|= n. • A set X is said to be infinite iff it is not finite. That is, if no bijection exists between [n] and X for any n ∈N. Let’s look at a simple example to see how this definition corresponds with our everyday understanding of counting. Example 21.2.1. Consider the set A = {Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday}. By counting the days, we find that |A|= 7. This process of counting, or enumerating the elements, can be viewed as constructing a bijection f : [7] →A. For instance, if we list the days from left to right, we define f(1) = Su, f(2) = Mo, f(3) = Tu, f(4) = We, f(5) = Th, f(6) = Fr, f(7) = Sa. Alternatively, if we list the days in reverse order, we obtain another bijection g : [7] →A defined by g(1) = Sa, g(2) = Fr, g(3) = Th, g(4) = We, g(5) = Tu, g(6) = Mo, g(7) = Su. Both functions confirm that A is a finite set with cardinality 7. While the notation |X|= n suggests that this value of n is unique, we need to establish that rigorously. Specifically, we will show that there cannot be two distinct natural numbers m and n such that |X|= m and |X|= n. Theorem 21.2.2 (Injection Criterion for Finite Sets). For all m, n ∈N, there exists an injection f : [m] →[n] if and only if m ≤n. Proof. Let m, n ∈N. (⇐): Suppose m ≤n. Define f : [m] →[n] by f(x) = x. This function is well-defined since [m] ⊆[n], and it is clearly injective because distinct elements of [m] have distinct images under f. (⇒): We prove the contrapositive. Assume m > n, and let f : [m] →[n] be any function. For each i ∈[n], define Ai = PreImf({i}). 133

 Each element of [m] belongs to exactly one of the sets A1, A2, . . . , An, and different Ai’s have no elements in common. Since m > n, the pigeonhole principle implies that at least one of these sets, say Ai, contains two distinct elements m1 ̸= m2. Then f(m1) = f(m2) = i, so f is not injective. This theorem confirms that if a set X is finite, its cardinality is uniquely determined. Thus, the formal definition of finite cardinality agrees perfectly with our usual, intuitive notion of “counting” elements. Corollary 21.2.3. If X is a finite set, then there exists a unique n ∈N such that |X|= n. Proof. Let X be a finite set. Suppose, for contradiction, that there exist distinct m, n ∈ N such that |X|= m and |X|= n. Then there are bijections f : [n] →X and g : [m] →X. Without loss of generality, assume m > n. Consider the composition f−1 ◦g : [m] →[n]. This map is a bijection, since it is the composition of two bijections. In particular, it is an injection from the larger set [m] into the smaller set [n], contradicting the injection criterion established above. Therefore, it is impossible for two different values m and n to satisfy |X|= m = n. Hence, the value of n ∈N such that |X|= n is unique. A few additional corollaries are worth noting. Corollaries 21.2.4. 1. For all n ∈N, every subset of [n] is finite. 2. If f : A →B is an injection and B is finite, then |A|≤|B|. In particular, if A ⊆B, then |A|≤|B|. 3. If g : A →B is a surjection and A is finite, then |A|≥|B|. 4. If A is finite and B is any set, then |A ∩B|≤|A| and |A ∖B|≤|A|. Next, we mention two additional results concerning finite cardinality. The first pertains to the cardinality of Cartesian products, for which we will provide a formal proof in recitation. 134

 Theorem 21.2.5. If A and B are finite sets, then |A × B|= |A|·|B|. Proof. In recitation. The second result concerns the cardinality of unions. Before presenting the general theorem for determining |A ∪B|, we first need a lemma that addresses the case where the sets are disjoint. Lemma 21.2.6. If A and B are finite and disjoint sets, then |A ∪B|= |A|+|B|. Proof. Let A and B be finite and disjoint sets, and let |A|= m and |B|= n. Fix bijections f : [m] →A and g : [n] →B. Construct a function h : [m + n] →A ∪B by h(k) =    f(k), if 1 ≤k ≤m, g(k −m), if m + 1 ≤k ≤m + n. We will show that h is a bijection. • Injectivity. Let k1, k2 ∈[m + n] and suppose h(k1) = h(k2). ▶If both k1, k2 ≤m or both k1, k2 > m, then k1 = k2 since f and g are injective. ▶If k1 ≤m and k2 > m (or vice versa), then h(k1) ∈A and h(k2) ∈B, and hence h(k1) = h(k2) ∈A ∩B contradicting the assumption that A and B are disjoint. Hence h is injective. • Surjectivity: Let y ∈A ∪B. ▶Case 1: If y ∈A, then since f is surjective, there exists k ∈[m] such that f(k) = y. Thus h(k) = f(k) = y. ▶Case 2: If y ∈B, then since g is surjective, there exists ℓ∈[n] such that g(ℓ) = y. Then h(m + ℓ) = g(ℓ) = y. Therefore, h is surjective. Since h is both injective and surjective, it is a bijection. Hence |A ∪B|= m + n = |A|+|B|. The following theorem is a special case of a more general result we will discuss later in the combinatorics section, known as the Principle of Inclusion–Exclusion (PIE). 135

 Theorem 21.2.7 (PIE version 1). If A and B are finite sets, then |A ∪B|= |A|+|B|−|A ∩B|. Proof. Let A and B be finite sets. Observe that A ∪B = A ∪(B ∖A) and that A ∩(B ∖A) = ∅. By Lemma 21.2.6, |A ∪B|= |A|+|B ∖A|. Furthermore, since B = (B ∖A) ∪(B ∩A) and the two sets are disjoint, Lemma 21.2.6 also gives |B|= |B ∖A|+|B ∩A|. Rearranging, we have |B ∖A|= |B|−|B ∩A|. Substituting into the earlier expression yields |A ∪B|= |A|+|B|−|A ∩B|.

Basic Cardinality Comparisons There are various cardinalities of infinite sets, some of which may appear different in size but actually have the same cardinality. To illustrate this phenomenon, mathematician David Hilbert proposed the famous thought experiment known as Hilbert’s Hotel. 21.3.1. Hilbert’s Hotel Imagine a hotel with infinitely many rooms, enumerated by the natural numbers: 136

 22. October 24 22.1. Basic Cardinality Comparisons 22.1.1. Countable vs. Uncountable Sets The main distinction among infinite sets that we will discuss is whether they can be placed in bijective correspondence with N. Definitions. A set X is called: • countably infinite if there exists a bijection f : N →X. In this case, we denote its cardinality by |X|= ℵ0. • countable (also called listable or denumerable) if X is either finite or countably infinite. • uncountable if X is infinite but not countably infinite. Up to this point, every set we have encountered is countable. To justify the existence of uncountable sets, we first need to understand why ℵ0 represents the “smallest” infinite cardinality. To do this, we must establish two facts: 1. N is not finite, and 2. if X is an infinite set, then there exists an injection f : N →X. We begin by showing that N is infinite. Specifically, we will prove that there is no bijection f : [n] →N for any n ∈N. The key ingredient is the following lemma. Lemma 22.1.1. If A ⊆N is finite and non-empty, then A has a maximum element. Proof. We proceed by induction on n = |A|. • Base Case: n = 1. Let A = {a1} for some a1 ∈N. Then a1 = max(A). • Inductive Step: Let n ∈Z+ and assume any non-empty finite subset of N with cardinality n has a maximum element. Let A ⊆N with |A|= n+1, and enumerate 139

 A as: A = {a1, a2, . . . , an, an+1}. Consider B = A ∖{an+1}. Then |B|= n, so by the inductive hypothesis, B has a maximum element. Let ak = max(B) for some k ∈[n]. We consider two cases: ▶Case 1: ak < an+1. Then for all i ∈[n + 1], ai ≤an+1, so an+1 = max(A). ▶Case 2: ak > an+1. Then ak ≥ai for all i ∈[n + 1], so ak = max(A). In either case, A has a maximum element. By the principle of mathematical induction, the lemma follows. Theorem 22.1.2. The set N is infinite. Proof. Assume, for contradiction, that N is finite. Since N ̸= ∅, there exists n ∈Z+ and a bijection f : [n] →N. Then we may write N = {f(1), f(2), . . . , f(n)}. By Lemma 22.1.1, N has a maximum element, say f(k). However, f(k) + 1 ∈N, contradicting that f(k) is maximal. Hence N is infinite. We have already shown that infinite sets exist, with N serving as one example. To establish that N is the “smallest” infinite set, we will show that it can be injected into any infinite set. Theorem 22.1.3. For any set A, either A is finite or there exists an injection f : N →A. Note. This proof relies on the Axiom of Countable Choice (ACC), which permits making an infinite sequence of choices. We present a simplified overview below. Proof. Let A be a set. If A is finite, there is nothing to prove. Otherwise, assume A is infinite. We will construct an injection f : N →A inductively. For each n ∈N, define Nn = {0, 1, . . . , n}. Choose an arbitrary element a0 ∈A and set f(0) = a0. Now let n ∈N and assume distinct elements f(k) ∈A have been chosen for all k ≤n. Since A is infinite, the set A ∖{f(k) | k ∈Nn} is nonempty. By the ACC, select an element an+1 ∈A ∖{f(k) | k ∈Nn} and define f(n + 1) = an+1. Proceeding in this manner defines a function f : N →A. By construction, f(n + 1) /∈ {f(k) | k ∈Nn}, so f(m) ̸= f(n) whenever m ̸= n. Hence, f is injective. 140

 This theorem supports the claim that ℵ0 is the smallest infinite cardinality, since every infinite set has at least this cardinality. A few immediate corollaries follow from this theorem. Corollaries 22.1.4. 1. A set A is infinite if and only if there exists a subset B ⊆A such that |B|= ℵ0. 2. Every subset A ⊆N is either finite or has cardinality |A|= ℵ0. 3. If f : A →N is an injection, then A is countable. 22.1.2. Linear Ordering of Cardinalities We can define a linear ordering of cardinalities on the class of all sets based on two important set-theoretic theorems. Definition. Let S and T be sets. We define: 1. |S|≤|T| if and only if there exists an injection f : S →T. 2. |S|≥|T| if and only if there exists a surjection g : S →T. The definition of |S|≤|T| is motivated by the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder theorem, which we will explore below. Note. If A and B are finite sets and there exist injections f : A →B and g : B →A, then both f and g must be bijections. In particular, if |A|≤|B| and |B|≤|A|, then |A|= |B|. Question: Does this result extend to infinite sets? Answer: Not directly. Example 22.1.5. Consider the sets N and 2N = {x ∈N | ∃y ∈N, x = 2y}. Define functions f : N →2N by f(n) = 4n and g : 2N →N by g(n) = n. Both f and g are injections, but neither is a bijection. Although having injections in both directions does not imply that the injections themselves are bijections, it does imply that some bijection must exist between the two sets. This result is known as the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder Theorem (CBS Theorem). 141

 Theorem 22.1.6 (Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder (CBS) Theorem). Let A and B be sets. If there exist injections f : A →B and g : B →A, then there exists a bijection h : A →B. Proof. Assume that injections f and g exist. If Img(B) = A, then g is a bijection, and we are done. Otherwise, assume Img(B) ⊊A. Define the set S ⊆A as S = (A ∖Img(B)) ∪  [ n∈Z+ Im(g◦f)n(A ∖Img(B))  . Note that A ∖S ⊆Img(B). Let g−1 denote the inverse of g on the domain Img(B). Define the function h : A →B by h(x) = ( f(x) if x ∈S, g−1(x) if x /∈S. We claim that h is the desired bijection. • Injectivity: Suppose h(x) = h(y) for some x, y ∈A. We consider three cases: ▶Case 1: If x, y ∈S, then f(x) = f(y) implies x = y since f is injective. ▶Case 2: If x, y /∈S, then g−1(x) = g−1(y) implies x = y since g−1 is injective. ▶Case 3: Assume without loss of generality that x ∈S and y /∈S. Then f(x) = g−1(y) implies (g ◦f)(x) = y. Since x ∈S, we have x ∈Im(g◦f)k(A∖Img(B)) for some k ∈N, and thus y ∈Im(g◦f)k+1(A ∖Img(B)) ⊆S, contradicting the assumption that y /∈S. Hence, this case cannot occur. 142

 Therefore, h is injective. • Surjectivity: Let y ∈B be arbitrary. We consider two cases: ▶Case 1: If g(y) /∈S, let x = g(y). Then h(x) = g−1(x) = y, as required. ▶Case 2: If g(y) ∈S, then there exists some k ∈N such that g(y) = (g ◦f)k(x) for some x ∈A∖Img(B). Since k > 0, we can write g(y) = (g◦f)(z) = g(f(z)) for z = (g ◦f)k−1(x). Thus, y = f(z) and h(z) = f(z) = y. Therefore, h is surjective. Since h is both injective and surjective, we conclude that h : A →B is a bijection, and hence |A|= |B|. The CBS Theorem justifies our definition of |A|≤|B| when there exists an injection f : A →B. To establish |A|= |B|, it is often easier to show that there exist injections f : A →B and g : B →A than to construct an explicit bijection h : A →B. The CBS Theorem guarantees that if |A|≤|B| and |B|≤|A|, then |A|= |B|, providing the antisymmetry needed for a linear ordering. In practice, the CBS Theorem is used to confirm the existence of some bijection h : A →B without requiring the specific bijection constructed in its proof. To illustrate this, let us revisit Example 22.1.5. Example 22.1.7. Recall from Example 22.1.5 that we defined injections f : N →2N by f(x) = 4x and g : 2N →N by g(x) = x. Both f and g are injections, but neither is a bijection. To construct a bijection between N and 2N using the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder (CBS) Theorem, we begin by finding the complement of the image of g. Since Img(2N) = 2N, it follows that A ∖Img(B) is the set of odd natural numbers. Define S = (A ∖Img(B)) ∪Img◦f(A ∖Img(B)) ∪Img◦f◦g◦f(A ∖Img(B)) ∪· · · = {odd naturals} ∪{4 · odd naturals} ∪{16 · odd naturals} ∪· · · = {4m(2n + 1) | m, n ∈N}. The set S consists of numbers of the form 4m(2n + 1) for all m, n ∈N, capturing every element covered by the iterative application of f and g. Next, we construct the bijection h : N →2N: h(x) = ( 4x if x = 4m(2n + 1) for some m, n ∈N, x otherwise. This mapping sends each element of S to 4x, pairing it with a unique element of 2N, while leaving elements outside of S unchanged. To visualize this mapping, consider its action on the first few natural numbers: 143

You should verify for yourself that this mapping is indeed injective and surjective, confirming h as a bijection. Note, however, that while the CBS theorem ensures the existence of such a bijection, it does not necessarily yield the simplest one. A much simpler bijection is j : N →2N defined by j(x) = 2x, which is more direct but does not arise from the CBS theorem’s construction. Finally, our definition of ≥is motivated by the following theorem, which tells us that the existence of an injection one way is equivalent to the existence of a surjection the other way. The proof is an elegant application of the Axiom of Choice, which we are assuming throughout. Theorem 22.1.8 (Partition Principle). Let A be a nonempty set and B any set. There exists an injection f : A →B if and only if there exists a surjection g : B →A. Proof sketch. (⇒): Suppose f : A →B is injective. We define a surjection g : B →A as follows: for b ∈Im(f), set g(b) = f−1(b) (well-defined since f is injective). For b /∈Im(f), map b to an arbitrary fixed a0 ∈A. This covers all a ∈A since g(f(a)) = a. (⇐): Suppose f : B →A is surjective. Then for each a ∈A, PreImf({a}) is nonempty. By the Axiom of Choice, there exists a function g : A →B such that g(a) ∈ PreImf({a}) for all a ∈A. (i.e., We select one element from PreImf({a}) for each a ∈A.) This function g is injective: if g(a1) = g(a2), then applying f gives a1 = f(g(a1)) = f(g(a2)) = a2. 144

 23. October 27 23.1. Countable Sets Recall that a countably infinite set is a set S that has the same cardinality as N. This represents the smallest size of an infinite set, making it a natural starting point for exploring results about the sizes of infinite sets, which often defy intuition. For instance, we have already shown that there exists a bijection f : N →2N. This implies that |2N|= |N|, even though 2N ⊊N. In other words, there are just as many natural numbers as there are even natural numbers. We have also previously encountered bijections g : N →Z and h : N →N2. Thus, we can conclude that |2N|= |N|= |Z|= |N2|. Next, we will prove some important results about countable sets, beginning with a classic example. We will present two different proofs of this result: the traditional “snaking proof” and an alternative argument using the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder (CBS) Theorem. 23.1.1. Countability of the Rationals Theorem 23.1.1. The set of rational numbers Q is countably infinite. Proof. We aim to demonstrate the existence of a bijection f : N →Q. In other words, we seek an explicit way to enumerate all rational numbers so that every rational number appears at a finite position in the list. To do so, we arrange all rational numbers of the form a b in a two-dimensional array, where a ∈Z and b ∈Z+. Each entry of this array represents one rational number. We then traverse this array diagonally to ensure that every rational number is encountered within a finite number of steps. Since each diagonal contains only finitely many entries, this process covers the entire array. Beginning at 0, we “snake” our way through the diagonals, skipping any fractions that are not in lowest terms, as illustrated below. 146

 This traversal defines a function f : N →Q recursively, assigning to each natural number the corresponding rational number in the sequence. The beginning of this enumeration may be represented as follows: x 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 · · · f(x) 0 1 1 2 −1 2 −1 2 1 3 1 4 −1 3 · · · Every rational number appears exactly once in this list, and each appears at a finite index, establishing a bijection f : N →Q. Hence, Q is countably infinite. We now present an alternative proof that Q is countably infinite, this time using the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder (CBS) Theorem. For this proof, we assume the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, which we have partially established. Theorem 23.1.2 (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic (FTOA)). Every integer greater than 1 can be written uniquely as a product of prime numbers. We have already shown that every integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes. In a later section on number theory, we will prove the uniqueness of this factorization. For the purposes of this proof, we assume the full validity of the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic. Theorem 23.1.3. The set Q is countably infinite. Proof. We will construct injections f : N →Q and g : Q →N. By the CBS Theorem, this will imply |N|= |Q|. 147

 • Define f : N →Q by f(n) = n 1 . If f(m) = f(n) for m, n ∈N, then m = n, so f is injective. Hence |N|≤|Q|. • To construct an injection g : Q →N, note that every rational number can be written uniquely in reduced form as a b, where a ∈Z, b ∈Z+, and gcd(a, b) = 1. Define g : Q →N by g a b  = ( 2a · 5b if a ≥0, 3−a · 5b if a < 0 where a b ∈Q is in reduced form. We now verify that g is injective. Suppose g(x) = g(y), where x = a1 b1 and y = a2 b2 , with ai ∈Z, bi ∈Z+, and gcd(ai, bi) = 1 for i = 1, 2. We consider three cases: ▶Case 1: a1, a2 ≥0. Then g(x) = g(y) implies 2a15b1 = 2a25b2. By the FTOA, we have a1 = a2 and b1 = b2. ▶Case 2: a1, a2 < 0. Then g(x) = g(y) implies 3−a15b1 = 3−a25b2, and again the FTOA gives a1 = a2 and b1 = b2. ▶Case 3: Without loss of generality, suppose a1 ≥0 and a2 < 0. Then 2a15b1 = 3−a25b2. By the FTOA, this forces a1 = a2 = 0, contradicting a2 < 0. Therefore, g is injective, and |Q|≤|N|. By the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder Theorem, we conclude that |N|= |Q|, so Q is countably infinite. We have already seen that several familiar sets are countable. We now establish some general results that allow us to construct new countable sets from previously known ones. 23.1.2. Properties of Countable Sets Recall that |N2|= |N|. Using this fact, together with induction, we can prove the following result. Theorem 23.1.4. For any n ∈Z+, |Nn|= ℵ0. Proof. Recall that |N2|= |N|, and let f : N2 →N be a bijection. We proceed by induction on n ∈Z+. • Base Case: For n = 1, we have |N1|= |N|= ℵ0, which holds by definition. 148

 • Inductive Step: Suppose that for some n ∈Z+, we have |Nn|= ℵ0. Then there exists a bijection g : Nn →N. Define a function h : Nn+1 →N2 by h((a1, a2, . . . , an), an+1) = (g(a1, a2, . . . , an), an+1). We show that h is a bijection. ▶Injectivity: Suppose h((a1, . . . , an), an+1) = h((b1, . . . , bn), bn+1). Then, by definition of h, (g(a1, . . . , an), an+1) = (g(b1, . . . , bn), bn+1), which implies that g(a1, . . . , an) = g(b1, . . . , bn) and an+1 = bn+1. Since g is injective, it follows that (a1, . . . , an) = (b1, . . . , bn), and hence ai = bi for all i ∈[n + 1]. Thus, h is injective. ▶Surjectivity: Let (x, y) ∈N2 be arbitrary. Since g is surjective, there exists (a1, . . . , an) ∈Nn such that g(a1, . . . , an) = x. Then for ((a1, . . . , an), y) ∈ Nn+1, h((a1, . . . , an), y) = (g(a1, . . . , an), y) = (x, y). Hence h is surjective. Since h is both injective and surjective, it is a bijection. Finally, the composition f ◦h : Nn+1 →N is a bijection, since it is the composition of two bijections. Therefore, |Nn+1|= |N|= ℵ0. By the principle of mathematical induction, we conclude that |Nn|= ℵ0 for all n ∈ Z+. Combining this result with the properties of finite Cartesian products, we obtain the following theorem. Theorem 23.1.5 (Finite Product of Countable Sets is Countable). If n ∈Z+ and X1, . . . , Xn are nonempty countable sets, then n Y i=1 Xi = X1 × X2 × · · · × Xn is countable. Moreover, if at least one Xi is infinite, then Qn i=1 Xi is countably infinite. 149

 We’ve seen that we can take finite Cartesian products of countable sets and remain countable. For unions of sets, we can do even better. The following result shows that a countably infinite union of countably infinite sets is still countably infinite. Theorem 23.1.6. Suppose {An}n∈N is a family of countably infinite sets. Then [ n∈N An is countably infinite. Proof. Let A = S n∈N An. We will show that ℵ0 ≤|A| and ℵ0 ≥|A|. • Since A0 is countably infinite, there exists a bijection f0 : N →A0. Define g : N → A by g(n) = f0(n). Because f0 is injective, g is also injective. Hence ℵ0 = |N|≤|A|. • For each n ∈N, let fn : N →An be a bijection (which exists because |An|= ℵ0 by assumption). Define h : N2 →A by h(n, m) = fn(m). We will show that h is surjective. Let a ∈A be arbitrary. Then a ∈An for some n ∈N. Fix such an n. Since fn is surjective, there exists m ∈N such that fn(m) = a. Thus h(n, m) = fn(m) = a. Because a ∈A was arbitrary, h is surjective. Therefore ℵ0 = |N2|≥|A|. By the Cantor–Bernstein–Schr¨oder Theorem and the partition principle, it follows that |A|= ℵ0, as desired. Since a countably infinite union of countably infinite sets is countably infinite, it follows that when we take either fewer unions or smaller sets, the union remains countable. Corollaries 23.1.7 (A Countable Union of Countable Sets is Countable). 1. If |A|= ℵ0 and |B|≤ℵ0, then |A ∪B|= ℵ0. 2. If {Ai}i∈N is a family of countable sets, then A = S i∈N Ai is countable. 3. If {Ai}i∈[n] (for some n ∈Z+) is a finite family of countable sets, then A = S i∈[n] Ai is countable. Moreover: a) If |Ai|= ℵ0 for at least one i ∈[n], then |A|= ℵ0. b) If each Ai is finite, then A is finite with |A|≥max{|Ai|}i∈[n]. Note. Regarding part (3b) in the previous corollary, we will discuss a formula for determining |A| in the combinatorics section later in the semester. 150

input: Show that the following sets are countably infinite. (a) A = {f : {0, 1} →N | f is a function} (b) B = the set of circles in R2 whose centers have integer coordinates and whose radii have rational lengths. (c) C = {f : N →N | ∀x ∈N, f(x + 1) = f(x) + 1} (d) D = the set of all “words”, where a “word” is a finite string of letters from the English alphabet. 23.2. Uncountable Sets So far, we have shown that many different infinite sets share the same size as N. This might naturally lead to the question: do uncountably infinite sets even exist? In this section, we will not only demonstrate that uncountably infinite sets do exist, but also establish that there are multiple distinct sizes (cardinalities) among uncountably infinite sets. Our main proof technique will be a powerful method known as diagonalization. 23.2.1. Uncountability of the Real Numbers To show that the real numbers are uncountable, we need to establish that there is no possible way to enumerate them. How can we prove that such an enumeration cannot exist? As is often done in mathematics, we will proceed by contradiction. To make this argument concrete, we will describe real numbers using their decimal expansions and apply a diagonalization argument. A real number x ∈R can be represented in its decimal form as x = x0.x1x2x3 · · · , where x0 ∈Z is the integer part, and xi ∈N with 0 ≤xi ≤9 for i ∈Z+ represent the decimal digits. For example, 5 6 = 0.83333 · · · = 0.83. Technical Note: Decimal representations are not always unique. In particular, a decimal that ends with an infinite sequence of 9’s is equal to the corresponding decimal that ends with an infinite sequence of 0’s. (This is usually proved in Calculus 2 using geometric series.) For example, 0.499999 · · · = 0.50000 · · · . To avoid this ambiguity, we adopt the following convention: a decimal representation of x ∈R is said to be in normalized form if it does not end with an infinite string of 9’s. 151

(For those who have taken Calculus 2) Suppose that x ∈[0, 1) has two distinct decimal expansions: x = 0.a1a2a3 · · · , x = 0.b1b2b3 · · · , where ai, bi ∈{0, 1, . . . , 9} for all i. Let M be the smallest positive integer such that aM ̸= bM and assume that aM > bM. Prove that: • ai = bi for all 1 ≤i < M, • aM = bM + 1, • ai = 0 and bi = 9 for all i > M. With this convention in place, we can now use diagonalization to prove that there are uncountably many real numbers in the interval (0, 1). 152

 24. October 29 24.1. Uncountable Sets 24.1.1. Uncountability of the Real Numbers Theorem 24.1.1. The open interval (0, 1) is uncountable. Proof. Let f : Z+ →(0, 1) be an arbitrary function. We aim to show that f is not surjective. For each n ∈Z+, write f(n) in normalized decimal form as f(1) = 0.c1,1c1,2c1,3 · · · f(2) = 0.c2,1c2,2c2,3 · · · f(3) = 0.c3,1c3,2c3,3 · · · f(4) = 0.c4,1c4,2c4,3 · · · ... ... We will construct a number x ∈(0, 1) such that x /∈Im(f). Define x by specifying its nth digit xn as xn = ( 1, if cn,n ̸= 1, 2, if cn,n = 1. By construction, xn ̸= cn,n for all n ∈Z+. Thus x differs from f(n) in the nth decimal place for every n, meaning x ̸= f(n) for all n ∈Z+. Since x ∈(0, 1) and x /∈Im(f), it follows that f is not surjective. Because f : Z+ →(0, 1) was chosen arbitrarily, this shows that ℵ0 = |Z+|< |(0, 1)|. Therefore, the interval (0, 1) is uncountable. Note. The proof above illustrates the general idea behind diagonalization: given any attempt to list all elements of a certain set (for example, f(1), f(2), f(3), . . . ), we construct a new element that systematically differs from each listed one in at least one place. More precisely, the diagonalization strategy involves the following pattern: 1. Assume, for contradiction, that an enumeration of the set exists. 153

 2. Represent each element in a way that exposes infinitely many “coordinates” or distinguishable components (for example, digits of a real number, or values of a sequence). 3. Construct a new element by changing the nth coordinate (or component) of the nth listed element in a deliberate way. 4. Conclude that this new element differs from every element in the list, contradicting the assumption of a complete enumeration. The key feature of diagonalization is that the new element disagrees with the nth listed element in the nth component, ensuring that it is distinct from every item in the list. This strategy generalizes beyond decimal expansions. In each case, the heart of the argument is the same: no enumeration can capture every possible object once we can systematically construct one that escapes the list. Corollary 24.1.2. R is uncountable, and |R|= |(0, 1)|. Proof. Define f : (0, 1) →R by f(x) = ln 1 −x x  . Proving that f is a bijection was left as an exercise earlier. Since (0, 1) is uncountable and f is a bijection, it follows that R is also uncountable. Corollary 24.1.3. For any a, b ∈R with a < b, each of the following sets is uncountable: • (a, b) • (a, b] • [a, b) • [a, b] • (−∞, b) • (−∞, b] • (a, ∞) • [a, ∞) 24.1.2. Cantor’s Theorem Our diagonalization argument for the real numbers revealed that (0, 1) cannot be enumerated by the natural numbers. Cantor’s Theorem extends this idea even further: for any set S, the collection of all its subsets—its power set—is strictly larger than S itself. Theorem 24.1.4 (Cantor’s Theorem). For any set S, we have |S|< |P(S)|. 154

 Notes. • If S is finite, Cantor’s Theorem can be verified directly. In Homework 7, we proved that |P([n])|= 2n for all n ∈N, and it can be proven by induction that n < 2n for all n ∈N. • For infinite sets S, the theorem implies an infinite hierarchy of distinct infinite cardinalities, obtained by repeatedly taking power sets. For example: |N|< |P(N)|< |P(P(N))|< |P(P(P(N)))|< · · · Proof. Let S be an arbitrary set, and suppose g : S →P(S) is any function. Define a set T ∈P(S) by T = {x ∈S | x /∈g(x)}. We will show that T ̸= g(x) for any x ∈S. Let x ∈S be arbitrary. ▶Case 1: Suppose x ∈T. Then, by definition of T, we have x /∈g(x). Hence x ∈T but x /∈g(x), so T ̸= g(x). ▶Case 2: Suppose x /∈T. Then, by definition of T, we have x ∈g(x). Hence x /∈T but x ∈g(x), so again T ̸= g(x). Thus T ̸= g(x) for every x ∈S, meaning T is not in the image of g. Therefore g is not surjective. Since g : S →P(S) was arbitrary, no surjection from S onto P(S) exists, and hence |S|< |P(S)|. The construction in the proof is another example of diagonalization, where we created a new set T that disagrees with each g(x) regarding the membership of x. Example 24.1.5. To illustrate Cantor’s Theorem for the case S = N, we will show that no surjection f : N →P(N) can exist. Let f : N →P(N) be an arbitrary function, and define T = {n ∈N | n /∈f(n)}. We claim that T is not equal to f(n) for any n ∈N. To get some intuition, let us look at a few examples. • Suppose f(0) = {0, 3}. Then 0 /∈T because 0 ∈f(0), so T ̸= f(0). • Suppose f(1) = {5}. Then 1 ∈T because 1 /∈f(1), so T ̸= f(1). • Suppose f(2) = N. Then 2 /∈T because 2 ∈f(2), so T ̸= f(2). • Suppose f(3) = {1, 2, 4}. Then 3 ∈T because 3 /∈f(3), so T ̸= f(3). In each case, T differs from f(n) at the element n itself. More generally, for any n ∈N, we have two cases: 155

 ▶Case 1: If n ∈f(n), then n /∈T, so T ̸= f(n). ▶Case 2: If n /∈f(n), then n ∈T, so T ̸= f(n). Thus, for every n ∈N, the set T differs from f(n) in at least one element—specifically, at the “diagonal position” n. This pattern of constructing a new object that disagrees with the n-th object at the n-th coordinate is the essence of the diagonalization method. Since T ∈P(N) and T ̸= f(n) for all n ∈N, we conclude that f is not a surjection. Therefore, |N|< |P(N)|. Diagonalization thus provides a systematic way to construct an element not listed in any proposed enumeration. 24.1.3. Infinite Binary Sequences The technique used in Cantor’s Theorem also applies to other sets with infinite structure. One important example is the set of all infinite binary sequences. Although this result was proven in recitation, we restate it here to highlight its connection with Cantor’s argument. Theorem 24.1.6. Define {0, 1}N as the set of all infinite sequences consisting of 0s and 1s. That is, {0, 1}N = {⟨ai⟩i∈N | ∀i ∈N, ai ∈{0, 1}} . Then {0, 1}N is uncountably infinite. Cantor’s diagonal argument can be adapted to this setting by assuming we have an enumeration of all infinite binary sequences and then constructing a new sequence that differs from the n-th sequence at its n-th position. The resulting sequence cannot appear in the list, proving that no enumeration can include every element of {0, 1}N. Conceptually, this result is equivalent to Cantor’s Theorem for P(N): each infinite binary sequence can be viewed as the characteristic function of a subset of N. Thus, {0, 1}N and P(N) have the same cardinality, providing another example of how diagonalization exposes uncountable structures.

Show that the following sets are uncountable. (a) A = {f : N →{0, 1} | f is a function} (b) B = {f : N →N | f is a function} (c) C = {f : N →N | f is a bijection} 156

 (d) D = the set of infinite sequences of integers. (e) E = R ∖Q[ √ 2] where Q[ √ 2] = {x ∈R | ∃a, b ∈Q, x = a + b √ 2} 157

 Part V. Number Theory 158

 25. October 29 25.1. Introduction Number theory is possibly the oldest field of mathematics, and much of modern mathematics has its roots in it. The simplest description of number theory is the study of arithmetic. Number theorists investigate the fundamental properties of the integers, exploring their structure and relationships. At the heart of this field lies the study of prime numbers, which play a central role. Many of the most famous unsolved problems in mathematics are found in number theory, often characterized by their simplicity to state but difficulty to solve. Examples of Number Theoretic Results and Conjectures 1. There are infinitely many ordered triples of positive integers (x, y, z) such that x2 + y2 = z2. 2. Fermat’s Last Theorem: There are no ordered triples of positive integers (x, y, z) such that xn + yn = zn for any n ≥3. 3. Lagrange’s Four-Square Theorem: Every nonnegative integer can be expressed as the sum of four perfect squares. For example, 35 = 52 + 32 + 12 + 02. 4. Goldbach’s Conjecture: Every even integer greater than 2 can be written as the sum of two prime numbers. For example, 14 = 3 + 11 (or 14 = 7 + 7). 5. Twin Prime Conjecture: There are infinitely many pairs of prime numbers of the form (p, p + 2). To begin our study of number theory, we will first review some relevant definitions and results from earlier sections. • A natural number n > 1 is called prime if its only divisors are 1 and itself. In other words, if n is prime and n = ab for a, b ∈N, then either a = 1 or b = 1 (Lecture 11). • A natural number n > 1 is called composite if there exist a, b ∈N such that 1 < a ≤b < n and n = ab. In other words, n > 1 and is not prime. • The natural number n = 1 is called a unit. 159

 • Every natural number n > 1 is either prime or can be expressed as a product of prime numbers (Theorem 11.1.7). We now state a useful result that was proved in class on September 8, and repeat the proof here for reference: Theorem 25.1.1. Let m, n ∈Z be nonzero integers. If m | n, then |m|≤|n|. Proof. Let m, n ∈Z ∖{0} such that m | n. Then there exists an integer a ∈Z such that n = ma. Since the absolute value function is multiplicative, we have |n|= |m|·|a|. Because m and n are nonzero, a ̸= 0, which implies |a|≥1. Therefore, |n|= |m|·|a|≥ |m|·1 = |m|. The following corollary is an immediate consequence of the theorem. Corollary 25.1.2. Let m, n ∈Z. If m | n and n | m, then m = ±n. From the definitions and results above, we know that every composite integer n has a prime factor p < n. In fact, we can say more: every composite integer n has a prime factor p ≤√n. This observation provides a straightforward (though inefficient) method for checking whether a natural number n is prime. Theorem 25.1.3. If n ∈N is composite, then n has a prime factor p such that p ≤√n. Proof. Let n ∈N be composite, and express n as n = ab for some a, b ∈N with 1 < a ≤b < n. We first show that a ≤√n. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that a > √n. Then n = (√n)2 < a2 ≤ab = n, which yields the contradiction n < n. Therefore, a ≤√n. Let p be any prime divisor of a (possibly a itself, if a is prime). Then p ≤a ≤√n and, since p | a and a | n, it follows by transitivity that p | n. Example 25.1.4. Use the previous theorem to determine whether 91 or 97 is prime. Observe that √ 91 < √ 97 < 10, and the only prime numbers less than 10 are 2, 3, 5, and 7. To determine whether 91 or 97 is prime, we need to check if they are divisible by 2, 3, 5, or 7. 160

 • It is clear that 2 ∤91 (since 91 is odd) and 5 ∤91 (since 91 does not end in 0 or 5). We also find that 3 ∤91, but we notice that 7 | 91 and 91 = 7 · 13. Thus, 91 is composite . • Similarly, 2 ∤97 and 5 ∤97. Checking for divisibility by 3 and 7, we find that 3 ∤97 and 7 ∤97. Therefore, 97 is prime .

 26. October 31 26.1. GCDs, LCMs, and Linear Combinations By Theorem 25.1.1, if n is a nonzero integer, then n can have only finitely many divisors, since m | n implies |m|≤|n|. Because any two nonzero integers each have finitely many divisors, it is natural to define the greatest divisor common to both. In fact, we can relax this requirement so that only one of the integers must be nonzero. Definition. For a, b ∈Z, not both zero, an integer d is called a common divisor of a and b if d | a and d | b. Furthermore, d is called the greatest common divisor of a and b, denoted gcd(a, b), if d is the largest of their common divisors. Examples 26.1.1. 1. Consider m = 54 and n = 42. Set of divisors of 54 = {±1, ±2, ±3, ±6, ±9, ±18, ±27, ±54}, Set of divisors of 42 = {±1, ±2, ±3, ±6, ±7, ±14, ±21, ±42}, Set of common divisors = {±1, ±2, ±3, ±6}. Therefore, gcd(54, 42) = 6, the largest element from the set of common divisors. 2. gcd(−6, −15) = 3. Even though both integers are negative, the greatest common divisor is always taken to be positive. 3. gcd(0, 44) = 44. Since every integer divides 0, we have gcd(0, n) = |n| for any integer n ̸= 0. (The value gcd(0, 0) is undefined.) Since the divisors of −m are the same as those of m, it follows that gcd(m, n) = gcd(|m|, |n|). Therefore, we often restrict our attention to pairs of nonnegative integers. Definition. Let a, b ∈Z, not both zero. Then a and b are called relatively prime (or coprime) if gcd(a, b) = 1. The following theorem states that if we divide a and b by their greatest common divisor, then the resulting integers have no common divisors other than ±1. This simple but powerful result is foundational in the study of arithmetic. 162

 Theorem 26.1.2. Let a, b ∈Z, not both zero. If gcd(a, b) = d, then gcd a d, b d  = 1. Proof. Let a, b ∈Z, not both zero, and let d = gcd(a, b). Suppose n ∈Z+ divides both a d and b d. Then there exist integers k, ℓ∈Z such that a d = nk and b d = nℓ, which implies a = nkd and b = nℓd. Hence, nd is a common divisor of a and b. Since d = gcd(a, b), we must have nd ≤d, and therefore n = 1 because n, d ∈Z+. Thus, gcd a d, b d  = 1.
